the duty of the city attorney, in all cases where he is engaged, to see, so far as may be in his power, that justice be done
to the city. (1929 Code § 14-30; Ord. 1504 Art. VIII § 3)
1-11-4: DISCONTINUANCE OF CITY SUITS AND ACTIONS:
The city attorney may dismiss any suit instituted by or on behalf of the city whenever he shall be of the opinion that the
evidence is not sufficient to sustain the same. (1998 Code)
1-11-5: MONTHLY REPORT OF COURT WORK:
The city attorney shall make a monthly report to the city manager in which he shall report the status of pending legal
matters pertaining to the city together with such other matters in relation to his office as he may deem necessary or
proper or as the city manager may require. (1929 Code § 14-3; 1998 Code)
1-11-6: PROSECUTION; FEES:
The following provisions are authorized, and it is further declared that the fees are levied pursuant to the legal authority
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=470 47/923
of the city and are solely for the purpose of providing revenue to cover the costs of municipal prosecution of municipal
ordinances and traffic violations.
A. A municipality shall be entitled to a twenty five dollar ($25.00) prosecution fee for any violation of the city ordinance
violation or municipal traffic law, pursuant to 55 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/4-2002. Such fee shall apply to any
conviction, plea of guilty, award of supervision, or nolo contendere disposition. Such fee shall be taxed as costs to be
collected from the defendant, if possible, upon final judgment of the case. A municipality shall have a lien for such
prosecution fees on all judgments or fines procured by the municipal attorney from prosecutions.
B. In all actions for violations of any city ordinance or municipal traffic law, where a defendant is found guilty, pleads nolo
contendere, or is awarded court supervision, a prosecution fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) shall be assessed by
the clerk of the court and payable to the municipality as "prosecution fees". (Ord. 2010-33)
Chapter 12
COMMUNITY SERVICES DEPARTMENT
1-12-1: ESTABLISHMENT:
There is hereby created a Community Services Department for the City. (1998 Code)
1-12-2: OFFICE OF COMMUNITY SERVICES DIRECTOR:
The office of Community Services Director is hereby created. The Director shall be appointed by the City Manager. The
Director shall have control and supervision over all officers and employees assigned to the Department, subject to the
control of the City Manager. (1998 Code)
1-12-3: FUNCTIONS:
The Community Services Department shall perform the following functions:
A. Equal Opportunity Issues; Affirmative Action: Assist the City in meeting its obligations to provide equal employment
opportunity to women and minorities in City jobs and in projects funded by the City and oversee the City's affirmative
action program to provide opportunities for disadvantaged persons.
B. Youth Activities: Work with local governments and private organizations to optimize the availability of programs and
activities for youth.
C. Day Care Services: Operate the Eurma C. Hayes Day Care Center for the children of persons who are working or in
job training.
D. Specialized Services: Contract with community based organizations to provide specialized services such as youth
activities, senior citizens programs, and abused women.
E. Coordinate Service Delivery: Coordinate the efforts of the City and other organizations in the community which
provide human and social services in an effort to coordinate the delivery of services.
F. Fair Housing: Provide staff assistance for the enforcement of the City Fair Housing Ordinance.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=470 48/923
G. Affordable Housing: Coordinate affordable housing efforts in the community.
H. Grants: Prepare grant applications for activities related to the Department's functions.
I. Staff Support: Provide staff support to City advisory bodies as assigned. (1998 Code)
Chapter 13
CITY PROPERTY
1-13-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this Chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the following definition, unless specified
otherwise:
AFFIRMATIVE VOTE: When a vote is taken by the City Council on a motion, resolution or ordinance, all votes counted
toward the passage of the motion, resolution or ordinance shall be in the form of "yeas". If a City Councilmember
abstains, passes vote or refuses to vote, such will be counted as a "nay" vote.
CAPITAL OUTLAY: Vehicles, equipment, infrastructures of the City, or any other item, object or property which is of a
nonexpendable nature and recorded as fixed assets in the City's funds.
CITY: The City of Carbondale.
CITY COUNCIL: The current members of the Carbondale City Council.
CITY-OWNED: The ownership of which is held in right, title and interest by the City of Carbondale.
CITY PROPERTY: All property such as land, buildings, motor vehicles, furniture, and equipment now owned by the City
or which for City purposes is hereafter acquired and owned by the City, including all lands now owned or which are
hereafter acquired and owned by the City for cemetery purposes, shall constitute City property, unless and until disposed
of in such manner as may be provided by law, ordinance or the provisions of this City Code.
CONTRACTUAL SERVICES1: Any contract created for the use and service of the following: telephone, gas, water,
electric light, or power, towel and cleaning services, insurance, leases for all grounds, buildings, office or other space
required by the using agencies, rental, repair or maintenance of equipment, machinery and City-owned property. The
term shall not include professional and other contractual services which are in their nature unique and not subject to
competition.
CONVEYANCE: The transfer of property or the title to property from one person or entity to another by means of a
written instrument and other formalities.
CORPORATE AUTHORITIES: The members of the legislative body of any "municipality" as defined herein.
ENTERPRISE ZONE: That enterprise zone as designated by the Illinois Department of Commerce and Community
Affairs which encompasses portions of the City of Carbondale, City of Murphysboro and unincorporated Jackson County,
Illinois.
LEASE: An agreement whereby one party relinquishes his right to immediate possession of property to another while
retaining ultimate ownership.
MAI: Member of appraisal institute.
MUNICIPALITY: Whether used by itself or in conjunction with other words, shall mean and include any municipal
corporation or political subdivision organized and existing under the laws of the state of Illinois and including, but without
limitation, any city, village, or incorporated town, whether organized under a special charter or under the general act, or
whether operating under the commission or managerial form of government; any county, water district, school district,
trustee of school, board of education, sanitary district or sanitary district trustee, forest preserve district or forest preserve
district commissioner, park district or park commissioner, airport authority and township.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=470 49/923
PERSONAL PROPERTY: Includes materials, objects, goods, chattels, effects, and movable things, the ownership of
which is held in right, title and interest by a particular person or entity.
REAL ESTATE: See definition of Real Property in this section.
REAL PROPERTY: Includes lands, lands under water, structures and any and all easements, franchises and incorporeal
hereditaments and estates, and rights, legal and equitable, including terms for years and liens by way of judgment,
mortgage or otherwise.
SALE: An agreement whereby the seller transfers real or personal property to a buyer for a consideration.
STATE OF ILLINOIS: The state of Illinois or any department, commission, board or other agency of the state.
SUPPLIES: All supplies, materials, and noncapital outlay equipment.
SURPLUS: Action taken by a simple majority of the city council members then holding office upon determining that
certain property is no longer necessary, useful to, profitable, or in the best interests of the city. If not specified, the city
council may take action by passage of a motion.
VOTE: The city council may take action under this chapter by passing a motion, unless such action specifically calls for a
resolution or ordinance. The vote upon the motion, resolution or ordinance shall be a concurrent vote of the city council
members then holding office. All "yea" votes shall be counted toward the passage of the motion. If a city council member
abstains, passes vote or refuses to vote, such will be added as a vote to whichever side has the most votes on the
motion. (Ord. 97-165)
1-13-2: CITY COUNCIL VOTE REQUIRED:
Any action taken by the city council under this chapter shall be pursuant to a motion and approved by a vote of two-thirds
(2/3) of those council members present, but at least four (4) votes are required, unless such action specifically requires
action to be taken by a resolution or ordinance or approved by a simple majority vote of those council members present.
(Ord. 2005-46)
1-13-3: SURPLUS BY SIMPLE MAJORITY VOTE:
By motion, the city council may take action to surplus real or personal property under this chapter, when, in the opinion of
a simple majority of the council members present, the property is no longer necessary, useful to, profitable, or in the best
interests of the city to retain. (Ord. 2005-46)
1-13-4: CONSIDERATION PAID THROUGH PLEDGING OF TAXES:
If the city enters a purchasing contract or lease for the purpose of purchasing or leasing real or personal property, and
said contract or lease agreement provides for the consideration to be paid in installments over a period of time through
the pledging of future property taxes, the city shall follow the statutory procedures pursuant to 65 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/11-76.1 et seq. (Ord. 97-165)
1-13-5: PROCEEDS OF SALE, LEASE OR CONVEYANCE:
Proceeds of the sale, lease or conveyance of real or personal property pursuant to this chapter shall be deposited in the
appropriate fund account per generally accepted accounting procedures (GAAP). (Ord. 97-165)
1-13-6: AUTHORIZATION:
The city council hereby gives authorization for the following transactions in order to carry out the intent and purpose of
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=470 50/923
this chapter:
A. Leases: Unless otherwise stated herein, the city manager, or his designee, shall be authorized to enter into any lease
agreement on behalf of the city, as lessor or lessee, for the purpose of leasing real estate or personal property,
subject to city council approval if required by this chapter. Such lease shall be signed by the city manager on behalf
of the city and shall be attested by the city clerk under the city seal. Such lease shall be executed by the other party
to the lease in such manner as may be necessary to legally bind the party to the lease agreement. Any lease for real
estate, upon execution by both parties, shall be duly recorded in the county clerk's office of Jackson County, Illinois.
B. Contracts: Unless otherwise stated herein, the city manager, or his designee, shall be authorized to enter into any
contract, document or agreement on behalf of the city for the purchase, sale or conveyance of real estate or personal
property, subject to city council approval if required by this chapter.
C. Deeds For Conveyance Of Real Estate: Upon the city council conveying or selling real estate pursuant to this chapter,
the mayor shall execute any deed or other evidence of transfer of title on behalf of the city along with the city clerk
attesting to such execution for the purpose of selling, conveying or accepting real estate. After being so executed, the
deed shall be duly recorded in the county clerk's office of Jackson County, Illinois. (Ord. 97-165)
1-13-7: PURCHASE OF REAL ESTATE:
The city may purchase real estate upon passage of a resolution by an affirmative vote of two-thirds (2/3) of those council
members present, but at least four (4) votes are required, through one of the following methods:
A. Upon the city council's determination that acquiring said property is in the best interests of the city or that said
property is necessary for a specific public purpose.
B. Upon the city council's determination that acquiring said property is in the best interests of the city for the public
purpose of promoting economic, industrial, commercial or residential development or redevelopment within the city.
The city manager shall be authorized to enter into a contract or agreement for the purchase of the real property. (Ord.
2005-46)
1-13-8: SALE OF CITY OWNED REAL ESTATE:
Real estate owned by the city shall be sold by one of the following methods as determined appropriate by the city
council:
A. Bidding Process: Upon the adoption of an ordinance by a vote of two-thirds (2/3) of the city council members then
holding office, the city council may authorize the sale of real estate. Said ordinance shall specify the location of the
real estate, the use thereof, and such conditions with respect to further use of the real estate as the city council may
deem necessary and desirable to the public's interest. Upon the adoption of said ordinance, notice shall be published
once each week for three (3) successive weeks in a daily or weekly newspaper of general circulation in the city. The
first publication shall be not less than thirty (30) days before the day provided in the notice for the opening of bids for
the real estate. The notice shall advertise for bids, contain an accurate description of the property, state the purpose
for which it is used, when the bids will be opened, and at what city council meeting the bids will be considered. All
bids shall be opened in public by the city manager, or his designee. The bids shall be presented to the city council for
consideration at a regular or special city council meeting. The city council may accept the high bid or any other bid
determined to be in the best interests of the city by a vote of two-thirds (2/3) of the city council members then holding
office; but a simple majority vote of the city council members then holding office may reject any and all bids. The
consideration for such a sale may include, but need not be limited to, the provision of off street parking facilities by
the purchaser, which parking facilities may be made part of the municipal parking system. Such consideration may
also include the provision of other public facilities by the purchaser.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=470 51/923
B. Alternative Process: The city may, upon passage of a resolution by a vote of two-thirds (2/3) of the city council
members then holding office, authorize the sale or public auction of surplus real estate. The value of the real estate
shall be determined by a written MAI certified appraiser or by a written certified appraisal of a state certified or
licensed real estate appraiser. The appraisal shall be available for public inspection. The resolution may direct the
sale to be conducted by the city manager or his designee; by listing with any local licensed real estate agency, in
which case the terms of the agent's compensation shall be included in the resolution; or by public auction. The
resolution shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city at the first opportunity following its
passage. The resolution shall also contain pertinent information concerning the size, location, use, and zoning of the
real estate and the terms of sale. The city council may accept any contract proposal determined to be in the best
interests of the city by a vote of two-thirds (2/3) of the city council members then holding office, but in no event at a
price less than eighty percent (80%) of the appraised value.
C. Conveyance Of Surplus Real Property: Any real property, that is acquired or held by the city of Carbondale for any
purpose whatsoever, may be conveyed to any person, entity, corporation, organization or agency, upon the city
council's determination that such real property is no longer necessary, appropriate, required for the use of, profitable
to or for the best interests of the city of Carbondale, upon the adoption of an ordinance by a vote of two-thirds (2/3) of
the city council members then holding office. Notice of the proposed sale or conveyance shall be published in a
newspaper of general circulation in the city no less than seven (7) days and no more than thirty (30) days prior to the
meeting at which the ordinance shall be considered by the city council. The notice shall contain a general description
of the property, the purpose for which it is to be used by the purchaser, the terms of the conveyance or sale, and the
benefits to the community to be served thereby. The city manager is hereby authorized to negotiate the terms,
conditions and consideration for the sale or conveyance.
D. City Manager/Real Estate Agencies/Public Auction:
1. If the city has either: a) adopted an ordinance to sell public real estate, pursuant to subsection A of this section, but
has received no bid on a particular parcel; or b) adopted a resolution to sell surplus public real estate under
subsection B of this section and has received no acceptable offer on a particular parcel within six (6) months after
passage of the resolution, then the city council may, upon passage of a resolution by a vote of two-thirds (2/3) of
the city council members then holding office, authorize that parcel of real estate be sold in one of the following
manners:
a. Authorize the city manager to negotiate the sale of real estate;
b. List the real estate with any local licensed real estate agency; or
c. Sell the real estate by public auction.
2. The resolution shall include the terms of the sale, the compensation of the agent (if any), the time and place of the
auction (if applicable), a legal description of the property and its size, and the use and zoning of the property. The
resolution shall be published once each week for three (3) successive weeks in a newspaper of general circulation
in the city on a daily or weekly basis. No sale may be conducted until at least thirty (30) days after the first
publication. The city council may, by a vote of two-thirds (2/3) of the city council members then holding office,
accept any offer or bid determined to be in the best interests of the city.
E. Economic, Industrial, Commercial Or Residential Development Or Redevelopment: The city council may convey or
sell real estate which has been purchased by the city for promoting economic, industrial, commercial, or residential
development or redevelopment within the city or when other city owned real estate is no longer necessary,
appropriate, required for the use of, profitable to or for the best interests of the city but instead would be of value to
promote economic, industrial, commercial or residential development or redevelopment within the city, upon the
adoption of an ordinance by a vote of two-thirds (2/3) of the city council members then holding office, at a regular or
special meeting. Notice of the proposed sale or conveyance shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation
in the city at least seven (7) days but not more than thirty (30) days prior to the meeting at which the ordinance is
considered by the city council. The notice shall contain a description of the property, the purpose for which it is to be
used by the purchaser, the terms of the conveyance or sale (including the sale price, if any), and the benefits to the
community to be served thereby. The city manager is hereby authorized to negotiate the terms, conditions and
consideration of the sale or conveyance. When considering the ordinance, the city council may take into
consideration factors such as the number of jobs to be created, the amount of increase to the community's tax base,
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=470 52/923
long term economic, industrial, commercial or residential growth, and the physical development or redevelopment of
the community.
F. Sale Of City Owned Real Estate In An Enterprise Zone: Upon being declared surplus, the city may dispose of unused
structures or vacant land owned by the city and located within an enterprise zone, through any method for conveying
real estate pursuant to this chapter, upon the adoption of an ordinance by a vote of two-thirds (2/3) of the city council
members then holding office. Upon the city establishing an urban homestead or shopstead program, disposal of real
estate under such programs shall be pursuant to 20 Illinois Compiled Statutes 655/10 et seq., or as hereafter
amended.
G. Real Estate Acquired By State Or Federal Funding: If the city has acquired real estate with funds from the state or the
United States and a condition of the receipt of such funds was that the real estate would be sold in a manner
prescribed by the state or the United States and said conditions and prescriptions remain in effect at the time of the
proposed sale, then the sale shall be in conformity with said conditions and prescriptions. Such sale shall be
approved upon the adoption of an ordinance by an affirmative vote of two-thirds (2/3) of the city council members then
holding office.
H. Cemetery Property: The sale of city owned cemetery spaces, lots and blocks shall be pursuant to title 6, chapter 2 of
this code.
I. Exchange Of City Owned Real Estate: The city may exchange real estate for property held by another party when the
following conditions are met:
1. A public hearing on the proposal to exchange real estate shall be held by the city council at a time and place to be
designated by them upon such proposal, pursuant to notice of public hearing duly published in a newspaper of
general circulation in the city. Said notice shall be so published not less than fifteen (15) days nor more than thirty
(30) days prior to the date of the hearing, shall set forth a legal description of the property or properties to be
exchanged, as well as the property or properties that the city is to receive through such exchange, and the
proposed terms and conditions otherwise of such exchange.
2. After the conclusion of said public hearing, the city council may, upon adoption of an ordinance by a vote of twothirds
(2/3) of the city council members then holding office, authorize the exchange proposed, or as modified by the
city council after the public hearing. The authorization shall state the following findings that: a) the premises to be
conveyed by the city under such exchange is no longer necessary, useful to, or in the best interests of the city; b)
the premises to be received by the city under such exchange will prove useful to the public's interests; and c) the
total value of the substitutional premises is approximately equal to or exceeds the value of the premises for which
same is being exchanged, as determined by the city council, taking into consideration the long term best interests
of the public.
J. Easements To Public Utility Services: The city may, upon the adoption of an ordinance by a vote of two-thirds (2/3) of
the city council members then holding office, convey or grant an easement to public utility companies or entities for
the use of city owned real estate upon determining that such conveyance would be in the best interests of the city.
Any easement conveyed pursuant to this subsection shall be executed by the mayor, attested to by the city clerk and
duly recorded in the Jackson County clerk's office. (Ord. 2012-44)
1-13-9: LEASE OF CITY OWNED REAL ESTATE:
The city may lease real estate by one of the following methods:
A. City As Lessor: Real estate owned by the city may be leased by one of the following methods based on the proposed
duration of the lease, unless otherwise specified in this section:
1. More Than Twenty Years, Less Than Ninety Nine Years: The city may lease city owned real estate for a term in
excess of twenty (20) years and not more than ninety nine (99) years, upon the adoption of an ordinance by a vote
of two-thirds (2/3) of those council members present, but at least four (4) votes are required, during a regular or
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=470 53/923
special meeting. Notice of the meeting shall be published at least once in a newspaper of general circulation in the
city not less than fifteen (15) nor more than thirty (30) days before the date of the meeting at which the ordinance
will be considered. The notice shall contain an accurate description of the property, the purpose for which it is used,
the restrictions upon the proposed use of the property to be leased, and the time and place of the regular or special
city council meeting at which the ordinance will be considered. The city manager may negotiate the consideration
and terms of such lease and enter into it on behalf of the city. Such consideration may include the provision of off
street parking facilities by the lessee, which parking facilities may be made part of the municipal parking system,
and provisions for other public facilities on the real estate acquired. The city council may contract with the lessee
for the use of a portion of a structure or improvements to be constructed on the real estate leased. The duration of
the lease shall not exceed ninety nine (99) years.
2. More Than Two Years, Twenty Years Or Less: The city may lease city owned real estate for a term in excess of
two (2) years but not in excess of twenty (20) years, upon the adoption of an ordinance by a vote of two-thirds (2/3)
of those council members present, but at least four (4) votes are required, without publication of notice in a
newspaper. The city manager is authorized to negotiate the consideration and terms of the lease and enter into it
on behalf of the city.
3. Two Years Or Less: The city manager is hereby authorized to lease city owned real estate for a term not to exceed
a period of two (2) years, and in such manner as the city manager may determine.
4. Intergovernmental Lease: The city may, upon the adoption of an ordinance by a vote of two-thirds (2/3) of those
council members present, but at least four (4) votes are required, lease to any other municipality, the United States,
the state, or any proper agency thereof, any real property owned or held by the city, or any part thereof or interest
therein, upon such terms and conditions and for such uses as may be agreed upon by the city council and the
representative authorities of the governmental agency for any period of time not to exceed fifty (50) years.
5. Lease Of Space Around City Buildings: The city may, upon adoption of an ordinance by a vote of two-thirds (2/3) of
those council members present, but at least four (4) votes are required:
a. Lease the space above and around buildings located on land owned or otherwise held by the city to any person
for any term not exceeding ninety nine (99) years.
b. Lease any space over any street, alley, or other public place, in the city, more than twelve feet (12') above the
level of the street, alley, or other public place, to any person who owns a fee simple or a leasehold estate, for a
term not less than that of the proposed lease, in the property on both sides of the portion of the street, alley, or
other public place so to be leased, whenever the city council is of the opinion that the space is not needed for
street, alley, or other public purpose, and that the public interests will be subserved by such leasing. Such lease
shall be for a term not exceeding ninety nine (99) years.
c. A lease created pursuant to this subsection A5 shall by its terms specify the purpose for which the leased space
may be used. If the purpose is to erect in the space of a building above or around a building owned by the city,
the lease: 1) shall contain a reasonably accurate description of the building to be erected and of the manner in
which it shall be imposed upon or around the existing building of the city, 2) shall contain a provision granting to
the city the option of renting for municipal use from the lessee any part of the building to be erected and stating
the terms upon which this option may be exercised as well as the rent which, after exercise of this option, shall
be paid by the city, and 3) shall contain a provision granting to the city the option to purchase for municipal use
the entire building to be erected in the space leased and stating the terms upon which this option may be
exercised and the price which shall be paid for the building by the city in the event it exercises this option to
purchase.
d. Any building erected in the space leased, by exercise of the power granted by this subsection A5, which is
above or around buildings located on land owned or otherwise held by the city shall be operated, as far as
practical, separately and apart from any building owned or operated by the city. No liability shall in any manner
attach to the city by reason of the election or operation of the building space so leased.
B. City As Lessee: The city may lease real property in the following manner:
1. Lease For Public Purpose: The city may lease real property for public purposes pursuant to a lease and/or
purchase agreement, which may provide that the city may, at its option, purchase the property which is subject to
the agreement or lease upon terms wherein payments previously made, or a portion of them, are deducted from
the purchase price of the property as provided for in such lease or agreement. Such lease shall be approved by
adoption of an ordinance by an affirmative vote of two-thirds (2/3) of those council members present, but at least
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=470 54/923
four (4) votes are required. If the option to purchase is acted upon, the city council shall purchase the real property,
pursuant to section 1-13-7 of this chapter.
2. Lease From Governmental Agency: The city may lease for any term not to exceed fifty (50) years from any other
municipality, state or federal agency, real property owned or held by the other municipality, state or federal agency,
or any part thereof or interest therein, upon such terms and conditions and for such uses as may be agreed upon
by the city council and the corporate authorities of the other municipality, state or federal agency in the same
manner provided in section 1-13-10 of this chapter. Such lease shall be approved by adoption of an ordinance
upon a vote of two-thirds (2/3) of those council members present, but at least four (4) votes are required.
3. Two Years Or Less: The city manager is hereby authorized to lease real estate for city purposes for a term not to
exceed a period of two (2) years, and in such manner as the city manager may determine. (Ord. 2005-46)
1-13-10: INTERGOVERNMENTAL TRANSFERS OF REAL ESTATE:
The city may take the following action:
A. Local Government:
1. The city may grant or convey real estate or any portion thereof to another municipality upon such terms as may be
agreed upon by the city council and the corporate authorities of the other municipality, upon adoption of an
ordinance by a vote of two-thirds (2/3) of those council members present, but at least four (4) votes are required,
and duly recorded in the Jackson County clerk's office.
2. The city may purchase or accept real estate or any portion thereof from another municipality upon such terms as
may be agreed upon by the city council and the corporate authorities of the other municipality, upon a vote of twothirds
(2/3) of those council members present, but at least four (4) votes are required. The city shall thereafter have
the right to use, occupy or improve the real estate so transferred for any municipal or public purpose.
3. The transfer of two (2) or more parcels of real estate between the city and another municipality at the same time
and in the same proceeding may be done in the manner provided in subsections A1 and A2 of this section.
B. State And Federal Governments: The city may take the following action:
1. The city may, upon adoption of an ordinance by a vote of two-thirds (2/3) of those council members present, but at
least four (4) votes are required, transfer all of the right, title and interest held by the city immediately prior to such
transfer, in and to any real estate, whether located within or without the city, to the state, or any authorized agency
thereof, upon such terms and conditions as may be agreed upon by the city council and the state, or in
consideration of a grant or loan of money by the United States, the state, or any agency thereof, for the
construction, extension, or improvement of any public works project or municipal building.
2. Upon adoption of an ordinance by a vote of two-thirds (2/3) of those council members present, but at least four (4)
votes are required, the city may donate, sell, lease, or convey any land heretofore acquired to the state or any
agency thereof, to be used as a site for an armory for the national guard or naval militia, and to acquire land for
these purposes.
C. Transfer For School Or Academic Purposes:
1. The city may, by the adoption of an ordinance by a vote of two-thirds (2/3) of those council members present, but at
least four (4) votes are required, convey real property that has been conveyed to the city for school or academic
purposes, to the school officials or officers authorized to hold it, for the use of the school district in which the real
estate is situated. All monies which may remain in the city's funds to the credit of any fund connected with the use
of such real estate, while so held by the city, shall be used by the city for any lawful corporate purpose.
2. When authorized by the adoption of an ordinance by a vote of two-thirds (2/3) of those council members present,
but at least four (4) votes are required, the city may sell and convey city owned real estate, or the city's interest
therein, to the trustee of the schools of the township or other county board of school trustees, as the case may be,
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=470 55/923
in which the real estate is situated, to be used as a school site for the school district in which the real estate is
situated.
3. As a condition of the sale, if any real estate conveyed by virtue of this subsection ceases at any time to be used for
school purposes for a period of three (3) years, the school officers, holding the title to the real estate, shall convey
the real estate back to the city to be held, enjoyed, and disposed of thereafter as other city owned property. A
provision expressing this condition shall be inserted in the deed made by the city, pursuant to this subsection. (Ord.
2005-46)
1-13-11: VACATION OF STREETS OR ALLEYS:
A. Upon the city council's determination that the public interest will be served thereby, the city council may adopt an
ordinance to vacate a street or alley or a part thereof, upon an affirmative vote of two-thirds (2/3) of those council
members present, but at least four (4) votes are required, during a regular or special city council meeting. Notice of
the meeting and subject matter of the ordinance to be considered shall be published at least once in a newspaper of
general circulation in the city, not less than fifteen (15) days before the meeting. The ordinance may provide that it
shall not become effective until the owners of all property or the owners of a particular parcel or parcels of property
abutting upon the street or alley, or part thereof so vacated, shall pay compensation in an amount which, in the
judgment of the city council, shall be the fair market value of the property acquired or of the benefits which will accrue
to them by reason of that vacation. If there are any public service facilities in such street or alley, or part thereof, the
ordinance may also reserve to the city or to the public utility, as the case may be, owning such facilities, such
property, rights of way and easements as, in the judgment of the city council, are necessary or desirable for
continuing public service by means of those facilities and for the maintenance, renewal and reconstruction thereof. If
the ordinance provides that only the owner or owners of one particular parcel of abutting property shall make
payment, then the owner or owners of the particular parcel shall acquire title to the entire vacated street or alley, or
the part thereof vacated.
B. The determination of the city council that the nature and extent of the public use or public interest to be subserved is
such as to warrant the vacation of any street or alley, or part thereof, is conclusive, and the passage of such an
ordinance is sufficient evidence of that determination, whether so recited in the ordinance or not. The relief to the
public from further burden and responsibility of maintaining any street or alley, or part thereof, constitutes a public use
or public interest authorizing the vacation. (Ord. 2005-46)
1-13-12: PURCHASE OF PERSONAL PROPERTY:
Personal property may be purchased by the city pursuant to either of the following methods:
A. Purchase Of Personal Property Valued In Excess Of Ten Thousand Dollars: The city may, upon a vote of a simple
majority of those council members present, authorize the purchase of personal property with an estimated value in
excess of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), in accordance with the provisions of chapter 6 of this title. The city
manager shall be authorized to enter into a contract, lease or agreement for such purchase2.
B. Purchase Of Personal Property Valued At Ten Thousand Dollars Or Less: The city manager is hereby authorized to
purchase personal property, including, but not limited to, contractual services, supplies or capital outlays pursuant to
chapter 6 of this title, estimated in value at ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) or less, in accordance with the
provisions of chapter 6 of this title3. (Ord. 2005-46)
1-13-13: SALE/CONVEYANCE OF CITY OWNED PERSONAL PROPERTY:
Personal property owned by the city may be disposed of by one of the following methods:
A. Property In General: Upon the passage of a motion declaring the property surplus, the city council may, by a simple
majority vote of those council members present: 1) pass an ordinance authorizing the sale of personal property in the
open market, with or without advertising the sale, upon the receipt of competitive bids, pursuant to the formal contract
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=470 56/923
procedures as prescribed in chapter 6 of this title; or 2) by motion, authorize the city manager to convert that personal
property into some other form that is useful to the city; or 3) by motion, authorize the city manager to convey the
personal property as part payment on a new purchase of similarly used property4.
B. Property Valued At Ten Thousand Dollars Or Less: Personal property with an estimated value of ten thousand dollars
($10,000.00) or less, may be disposed of, conveyed or sold by the city manager in the open market, without prior city
council approval, without newspaper advertisement and without observing the procedures for awarding a formal
contract as prescribed in chapter 6 of this title. Provided, however, that any capital outlay property shall first be
declared surplus by a simple majority of the city council before being disposed of, conveyed or sold5.
C. Property Held By Police Department: This subsection applies to all property, other than real property, of which
possession is transferred to the Carbondale police department under circumstances supporting a reasonable belief
that such property was abandoned, lost or stolen or otherwise illegally possessed, except property seized during a
search, and retained and ultimately returned, destroyed or otherwise disposed of pursuant to order of a court in
accordance with 725 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/108-11, 5/108-12, 5/114-12 or other law hereafter applicable to
property of which custody and disposition is prescribed by 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/4-201 et seq.
1. Property believed to be abandoned, lost or stolen or otherwise illegally possessed shall be retained in custody by
the chief of police who shall make reasonable inquiry and effort to identify and notify the owner or other person
entitled to possession thereof, and shall return the property after such person provides reasonable and satisfactory
proof of his ownership or right to possession and reimburses the city for all reasonable expenses of such custody.
2. Weapons which have been confiscated as a result of having been abandoned or illegally possessed may be
transferred to the department of state police for use by the crime laboratory system, for training purposes, or for
any other application as deemed appropriate by the department, if no legitimate claim is made for the confiscated
weapon within six (6) months of the date of confiscation, or within six (6) months of final court disposition if such
confiscated weapon was used for evidentiary purposes.
3. If the identity or location of the owner or other person entitled to possession of the property has not been
ascertained within six (6) months after the Carbondale police department obtains such possession, upon approval
by the city manager, the chief of police shall either:
a. Effectuate the sale of the property for cash to the highest bidder at a public auction, notice of which (including
time, place and a brief description of such property) shall be published at least once in a newspaper of general
circulation in the city at least ten (10) days prior to such auction. Property offered but not sold at such public
auction may be offered and sold at a subsequent public auction without such notice; or
b. Transfer custody of the property to the city for use or disposal pursuant to this chapter, rather than effectuating
the sale of the property by public auction.
4. The owner or other person entitled to possession of such property may claim and recover possession of the
property at any time before its sale, upon providing reasonable and satisfactory proof of ownership or right to
possession and reimbursing the city for all reasonable expenses of custody thereof.
D. Intergovernmental Transfer Of Personal Property: Upon a vote by a simple majority of those council members
present, the city may convey, grant, transfer, or sell to a municipality, the United States, the state, or to any proper
agency thereof, any personal property owned by the city, upon such terms as may be agreed upon by the city
council, or in consideration of a grant or loan of money by the United States, the state, or any agency thereof, for the
construction, extension, or improvement of any public works project or municipal building.
E. School Purposes: Upon a vote of two-thirds (2/3) of those council members present, but at least four (4) votes are
required, the city may convey personal property that has been conveyed to the city for school or academic purposes,
to the school officials or officers authorized to hold it, for the use of the school district, by proper conveyance
executed by the city, under the corporate seal thereof. (Ord. 2005-46)
1-13-14: LEASE OF PERSONAL PROPERTY:
The city may enter into a lease for personal property in the following manner:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=470 57/923
A. Lease Valued In Excess Of Ten Thousand Dollars Or For Longer Than Two Years: If the lease of personal property is
for an estimated value in excess of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), or for a period longer than two (2) years, the
city council may authorize the city manager to enter into a lease, with the city as lessee or lessor, for such personal
property, as may be required for city purposes upon an affirmative vote of a simple majority of those council members
present.
B. Lease Valued At Ten Thousand Dollars Or Less And For Two Years Or Less: If the lease of personal property is for an
estimated value of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) or less and for a period of two (2) years or less, then the city
manager is hereby authorized to lease the personal property and enter into such lease agreement on behalf of the
city as lessee or lessor, without prior city council approval.
C. Lease Of Personal Property With Option To Purchase: If the city is granted an option to purchase leased property
subject to an agreement or lease, then payments previously made, or a portion of them, may be deducted from the
purchase price of the property pursuant to the lease agreement. If the total purchase price of the leased personal
property exceeds ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) in estimated value, then the city shall purchase the personal
property upon a simple majority vote of those council members present, pursuant to section 1-13-12 of this chapter. If
the total purchase price of the leased personal property does not exceed ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) in
estimated value, then the city manager is hereby authorized to purchase all or a portion of the leased property,
without prior city council approval.
D. Lease Of Personal Property With Local, State Or Federal Government: The city may, upon a vote of a simple majority
of those council members present, lease from a municipality, the United States, the state, or any proper agency
thereof, any personal property for use for any municipal purpose, for any period of time not to exceed fifty (50) years,
with or without an option to buy the property and with or without a clause to the effect that title to the leased property
shall vest in the city at the expiration of the lease.
E. Lease Of Equipment And Machinery: The city may, upon an affirmative vote of two-thirds (2/3) of those council
members present, but at least four (4) votes are required, authorize the city manager to enter into a lease for a period
not to exceed five (5) years for such equipment and machinery as may be required for city purposes. (Ord. 2005-46)
Chapter 14
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
ARTICLE A. BOARD OF LOCAL IMPROVEMENTS
1-14A-1: BOARD ESTABLISHED:
A. Establishment; Composition: There is hereby established a Board of Local Improvements for the City. This Board shall
consist of three (3) to five (5) members at the discretion of the City Manager.
B. Appointments: The City Manager shall appoint all of the members of the Board of Local Improvements. Such persons
may be appointed from persons holding other offices or positions in the government of the City. The City Manager
shall appoint an engineer to serve on the Board.
C. President Named: The City Manager shall appoint the President of the Board of Local Improvements.
D. Meetings: The Board shall meet at such times as it may determine or upon the call of the President thereof, and shall
have the powers and duties granted to it by statute. (Ord. 73-37 § 1)
1-14A-2: PROCEDURE FOR MAKING LOCAL IMPROVEMENTS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=470 58/923
The City hereby adopts, by reference, 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/9-2-1 et seq., and as amended from time to time,
as the procedure for making local improvements in the City. (Ord. 73-30 § 1)
ARTICLE B. COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT LOAN AND GRANT
REVIEW BOARD
1-14B-1: ESTABLISHMENT AND PURPOSE:
There is hereby established within the city a community development loan and grant review board. It shall be the
purpose of said board to review any and all requests for loans, or grants made to the city, or any division thereof, or to
any agency, individual, corporation, or any other entity which has a contract with the city, which contract provides that
said entity may make loans or grants which would result in the expenditure of, at least partially, community development
assistance program funds. Provided, further, that no loan or grant which results in the expenditure of community
development funds shall be made by the city, any division thereof, or any entity referred to herein which contracts with
the city, which results in the expenditure of community development funds, at least partially, unless said request has
been reviewed by the board established herein. It shall further be the purpose of said board to review facade
improvement loan requests submitted to the city for approval. The board may also review other loan and grant requests
referred to it by the city manager or city council. (Ord. 2007-40)
1-14B-2: MEMBERSHIP:
Said board shall be composed of five (5) persons who have had at least one year of experience in financial and business
matters, either as a businessperson who owns, operates or manages a business, or as an employee of a financial
institution, or a person who has received substantial professional training in financial areas. Said board shall be
appointed by the mayor, with the consent of the council. All terms on said board shall be for a period of three (3) years.
Any member may be removed by the mayor, with the consent of the council, without cause, notice or hearing. Members
may be removed by being notified, by the mayor, thirty (30) days prior to the removal date in writing, at the last known
address of the member and by the mayor making the recommendation to the council of a successor for said member. An
affirmative vote on a successor shall be approval by the council of the removal of the member being removed. The
replacement shall serve the remainder of the term of the member being replaced. (Ord. 2007-40)
1-14B-3: DUTIES:
A. Meetings: The board shall meet at least once annually in person and at such times as is directed by the chairperson
or at the request of three (3) members. The chairperson shall be appointed by the mayor. All requests for grants or
loans proposed to be made by the city or any division thereof, or by any entity contracting with the city from funds
enumerated as provided in this article shall be forwarded to the board after review by appropriate city staff. The board
shall review said request, and make recommendation to the city manager within thirty (30) days from the receipt of
said request. The board shall advise the city manager of its recommendation, which recommendation shall be
advisory only.
B. Seniority: The board shall be required to submit its recommendation of approval or disapproval of loan applications to
the city manager with the written signature of the board chairperson. In the event that a conflict of interest, absence,
or other event arises which renders the chairperson unavailable to fulfill their duties, the remaining board members
shall assume the approval authority of the chairperson based on seniority. Seniority shall be established by date of
appointment to the board with the earliest appointment being most senior.
C. Seek Additional Information: The board shall have the authority to request additional information concerning any loan
or grant request which the board feels is relevant, and shall have the authority with the consent of the city manager to
prescribe the form upon which said request shall be made.
D. Observe Confidentiality: Members of the board shall comply with the requirements of the city concerning ethics
disclosure, and shall complete the ethics disclosure form required by subsection 1-5-7D of this title. No member shall
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=470 59/923
make any recommendation concerning any loan or grant, or discuss any loan or grant request which involves a
relative within the second degree of kinship of any said member, or any request which will directly or indirectly
financially benefit the member. (Ord. 2014-34)
ARTICLE C. PERSONNEL BOARD
1-14C-1: ORGANIZATION:
The Personnel Board shall consist of seven (7) members who shall be selected in the following manner: the Mayor and
City Council shall appoint three (3) citizen members. Three (3) nonunion City employee members shall be chosen in an
election process conducted by the Personnel Officer. All nonunion City employees shall be eligible to vote in the election
and shall be eligible to be elected to the Personnel Board with the exception of the City Manager, the City Manager's
secretary, the City Manager's assistants and all administrative department heads. Those six (6) members shall then
choose a seventh member. Citizen members shall be qualified electors of the City and shall hold no salaried office or
employment in the City government, nor shall any of these three (3) members, while a member of the Board, be eligible
for appointment to any salaried office of employment in the service of the City. One of the citizen members may serve
simultaneously on the Board of Police and Fire Commissioners. The first appointees to the Board shall choose by lots for
terms as follows: three (3) members for three (3) years, three (3) members for terms of two (2) years, and one member
for a term of one year. After that, all members shall be appointed or elected, as the case may be, for a term of three (3)
years, except for replacements who shall serve until the end of the term of the member replaced. (Ord. 80-85)
1-14C-2: POWERS, APPEALS:
The Board shall have jurisdiction over any appeals submitted by any employee of the competitive service1. The Board
shall submit a written statement of facts, findings and recommendations to the City Manager. The Board's
recommendations shall be advisory in nature and the action taken by the City Manager shall be final and conclusive. The
hearing may be open to the public if requested by the employee or the City Manager. (Ord. 1436 § 5)
1-14C-3: INVESTIGATIONS:
In addition to the authority to propose nonunion personnel rules and regulations and amendments thereto, the Personnel
Board shall also conduct any investigations it deems necessary for the purpose of making recommendations concerning
nonunion personnel rules and regulations and amendments thereto to the City Manager or the City Council. (Ord. 84-50)
1-14C-4: POWER TO SUBPOENA WITNESSES:
The Personnel Board shall have full power to subpoena witnesses and pertinent documents, which power may be
enforced by the Board by proper petition to any court of competent jurisdiction. The Board shall have power to administer
oaths and to take sworn testimony. (Ord. 1436 § 5)
1-14C-5: REMOVAL; VACANCIES:
Any member of the Board may be removed for cause at any time by the City Council. Vacancies from among the three
(3) citizen members of the Personnel Board, from whatever cause, shall be filled by appointment by the Mayor with
approval of the City Council for the unexpired term. Vacancies from among employee members shall be filled from the
runner-up of candidates for the last election. The first runner-up shall fill the first vacancy and so on. The term of
employee members shall automatically cease upon their separation from service, and any employee member shall be
disqualified to participate in any grievance proceeding provided for in this Code, wherein such employee is a party
aggrieved or complained against. In the event of such disqualification, the first runner-up shall take the disqualified
employee's place for such a proceeding. (Ord. 80-85; 1998 Code)
1-14C-6: COUNSEL AND SECRETARY:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=470 60/923
A. The City Attorney shall serve as the Personnel Board's legal advisor.
B. The Human Resources Manager or his designee shall serve as the Personnel Board's secretary. (Ord. 84-50)
ARTICLE D. CITIZENS ADVISORY COMMITTEE
(Rep. by Ord. 2003-39)
ARTICLE E. INFORMATION AND TELECOMMUNICATIONS
COMMISSION
1-14E-1: ESTABLISHMENT:
There is hereby established in the city a commission which shall be known as the Carbondale information and
telecommunications commission of the city. (Ord. 98-06)
1-14E-2: MEMBERSHIP:
Said commission shall be composed of seven (7) members and one city council member, appointed by the mayor, with
the consent of the city council. The chairperson and any other officers created by the bylaws of the commission shall be
elected by an affirmative vote of a majority of the commission members present and shall serve for the period specified
in the bylaws. (Ord. 2002-75)
1-14E-3: TERMS:
A. The original members shall be appointed for terms as follows:
1. Two (2) for one year terms.
2. Two (2) for two (2) year terms.
3. Three (3) for three (3) year terms.
B. All subsequent terms shall be for periods of three (3) years.
C. Members shall be residents of the city except as hereinafter provided, and the mayor shall make all reasonable efforts
to appoint to said commission representatives as follows:
1. At least one student from Southern Illinois University at Carbondale;
2. At least one representative from the office of the chancellorof Southern Illinois University, which representative
need not be a resident of the city but must live within the mile and one-half boundary of the city;
3. At least one representative from the College of Mass Communication and Media Arts, which representative need
not be a resident of the city but must live within the mile and one-half boundary of the city; (Ord. 2002-35)
4. At least four (4) other citizens of the city, who are subscribers to cable services in the city;
5. At least one city council member, who shall be an ex officio member with no right to vote. (Ord. 2002-75)
1-14E-4: BYLAWS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=470 61/923
The commission shall be empowered to organize and establish its own bylaws, not in conflict with this article. (Ord. 98-
06; 1998 Code)
1-14E-5: STAFF SUPPORT:
The commission shall receive reasonable support from the staff of the city manager's office of the city. All requests for
such support shall go to the city manager. (Ord. 98-06)
1-14E-6: MONETARY SUPPORT:
The commission shall be authorized to request such monetary support as it deems necessary from the city manager's
office. Said request shall be submitted by the city manager to the city council. (Ord. 98-06)
1-14E-7: PURPOSE:
A. Review Operations Of Cable Service Provider: It shall be the purpose of the commission to review the operations of
cable service providers in the city. In order to carry out such purpose, the commission is hereby authorized to carry
out the following functions:
1. Advise the city council on the following issues and matters:
a. Issues or matters which may constitute grounds for revocation of a franchise agreement in existence;
b. Disagreements among the franchisee, subscribers, and public and private users of the cable service;
c. Regulation of rates and application of said rates by the franchisee;
2. Make an annual report to the city council evaluating the cable service providers in the city. Such evaluation shall
take into account the amount of franchise fees received and distributed, total number of hours of utilization of public
channels, totals of various appropriating categories, plans submitted during the year by the franchisee for the
development of its services, and an evaluation indicating whether the franchisee is complying with the franchise
agreement between the franchisee and the city;
3. Advise the city manager of the city, if requested, concerning the audit of franchisee records which are required to
be kept. In addition, the commission may request such other information in addition to that required herein which
would aid in analyzing and evaluating cable service system operations. Such requests shall be within the scope of
the franchise agreement between the city and the franchisee;
4. Investigate complaints at the discretion of the commission filed by any subscriber to a cable service provider in the
city. Based on said investigation, the commission may request that the franchisee adjust billing charges or make
reasonable refunds. If the franchisee fails to cooperate with the commission concerning said requests, the
commission shall inform the city manager's office for further action if necessary; and
5. Encourage the use and access to cable service channels among the widest range of institutions, groups, and
individuals within the city.
B. Issues Involving Informational And Telecommunication Services: It shall be the purpose of the commission to address
and discuss issues involving informational services and telecommunication services, including, but not limited to,
matters involving the operations of telecommunication providers in the city. In order to carry out such purpose, the
commission is hereby authorized to carry out the following functions:
1. Conduct public hearings, to make investigations which it deems necessary and appropriate, and to do such other
and further acts which are required by, or incidental to the functions to be carried out by the commission;
2. Discuss current issues, changes, and services involving telecommunication providers and advise the city council
accordingly;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=470 62/923
3. Serve as an advocate for positive change in the telecommunications and informational service area by obtaining
information and conducting public forums or hearings on new or emerging telecommunication or informational
services and programs that will benefit the citizens of the city;
4. Conduct public hearings on current and proposed programs and services;
5. Assist the city manager in seeking financial support fromgovernment grants, corporations, foundations and other
sources for projects, programs, or services approved by the commission and the city council and prepare
proposals for such support to be considered by the city council;
6. Provide information to the community on issues and changes in telecommunication programs, services,
technology, personal privacy, government regulations, and proposed changes in local, state and federal law;
7. Utilize expertise and resources from Southern Illinois University at Carbondale to conduct surveys and research
pertinent to the above responsibilities; and
8. Transact other matters that may be referred or delegated to the commission by the city council. (Ord. 98-06)
1-14E-8: DUTIES:
In order to carry out the commission's purpose and function, the commission is authorized to conduct public hearings, to
make investigations which it deems necessary and appropriate, and to do such other and further acts which are required
by, or are incidental to the functions to be carried out by this commission. (Ord. 98-06)
ARTICLE F. SUSTAINABILITY COMMISSION
1-14F-1: CREATION; MEMBERSHIP; TERMS:
A. Commission Created: There is hereby created a committee which shall be referred to as the Sustainability
Commission and which shall consist of nine (9) members appointed by the Mayor with the advice and consent of the
City Council, seven (7) of whom shall be general members and two (2) of whom shall be student members.
B. Terms:
1. General Members: General members shall be appointed for three (3) year staggered terms. Each successive term
shall be for a period of three (3) years in accordance with a staggered schedule.
2. Student Members: Student members shall be appointed for two (2) year terms.
C. Membership; Qualifications:
1. General Members: All of the members shall reside within the corporate boundaries or within one and one-half
(11/2) miles of the corporate boundaries of the City. No less than two-thirds (2/3) of the members must reside within
the corporate boundaries. General members of the commission will be appointed to include a wide spectrum and
citizens with interests and expertise in environmental issues, energy use and planning, consumers, builders, and
contractors, students, landlords, utility representatives and others with interest in energy, environmental, and
sustainability matters.
2. Student Members: Student members shall reside within the City at the time of their appointment and shall maintain
such residence during their term on the Sustainability Commission with the exception of temporary absences
during school breaks. One student member shall be a student in good standing at Southern Illinois University at
Carbondale while the other student member shall be a student in good standing at Carbondale Community High
School. Both student members shall possess sustainability, energy related, or environmental academic
backgrounds or shall hold membership in sustainability, energy related, or environmental clubs or groups. (Ord.
2017-45)
D. Compensation: All members, both general and student members, shall serve without compensation. (Ord. 2009-43)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=470 63/923
1-14F-2: FUNCTIONS:
The Sustainability Commission shall advise the City Council concerning the following matters:
A. Recommendations for energy conservation provisions in the Building Code.
B. Study of possible incentives and financing methods of energy conservation and the use of renewable energy sources
such as solar energy.
C. Application of energy and environmental conservation principles within all facets of the City.
D. Increase energy efficiency in transportation.
E. Facilitation of interagency exchange of information, findings, and expertise in the field of energy conservation and
environmental issues.
F. Recycling and the use of recycled or reusable materials.
G. Utilization of new technology in sustainable resources to create energy conservation using sustainable and renewable
energy sources.
H. Provide information to the City Council of the City of Carbondale and the citizens of Carbondale concerning
sustainable environmental issues, and the utilization of sustainable and renewable energy resources.
I. Make recommendations concerning renewable and sustainable energy and environmental issues facing the city of
Carbondale. (Ord. 2009-43)
ARTICLE G. BOARD OF FIRE AND POLICE COMMISSIONERS
1-14G-1: CREATION:
There is hereby created a board of fire and police commissioners which shall consist of five (5) members who shall be
appointed by the mayor with the approval and consent of a majority of the city council. The term of office shall be three
(3) years and members shall serve until their successors are appointed and have qualified. No appointment shall be
made by any mayor within thirty (30) days of the expiration of his term of office. (1998 Code)
1-14G-2: QUALIFICATIONS; REMOVAL:
No person holding an office in the city shall be a member of the board. The acceptance of any such office by a member
of the board shall be treated as a resignation of his position as a member of the board. No person shall be appointed a
member of the board who is related either by blood or marriage, up to the degree of first cousin, to any elected official of
the city. Members are subject to removal for cause by a majority vote of the city council. (1998 Code)
1-14G-3: DEFINITIONS:
BOARD: The board of fire and police commissioners of the city.
FIREFIGHTER: Any person holding a position in the Carbondale fire department, except as hereinbelow modified.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=470 64/923
OFFICER: Any sworn officer holding a position in the Carbondale police department, except as hereinbelow modified.
(1998 Code)
1-14G-4: AUTHORITY OF BOARD:
A. The board of fire and police commissioners shall have the duty and authority to compile the register of eligibles
resulting from the examination process for original appointment in the classified service of the fire and police
departments; the promotional eligibility register for promotional appointments; and shall serve as the body to hear
appeals from any suspension, demotion or termination which may be imposed by the city manager against any police
officer or firefighter, and to hear appeals as a result of complaints brought against a member of the police or fire
departments by a member of the public. The board shall have no authority to discipline or discharge police officers or
firefighters.
B. The board of fire and police commissioners is created pursuant to 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/10-2.1. (1998 Code)
1-14G-5: MEETINGS:
A. Notice: Notice of regular or special meetings shall be posted in accordance with the open meetings act and open to
the public. During any regular or special meeting, a closed session may be held upon a proper motion made by a
member of the board. Closed sessions may be limited to board members and such invited persons as the board may
deem necessary.
B. Quorum: Three (3) members of the board shall constitute a quorum for the conduct of all business.
C. Chairperson: The board shall elect a chairperson at the April meeting to serve during the fiscal year. The chairperson
shall serve for one year or until a successor is duly elected and qualified. The board may designate one member to
serve as vice chairperson. (1998 Code)
1-14G-6: GOVERNING RULES:
A. Formulate And Distribute: The board shall formulate rules to carry out the purposes of these provisions. All rules and
revisions thereto shall be made available for distribution not more than ten (10) days from the date of adoption. (1998
Code)
B. Substance And Application: The governing rules shall apply only to the examination process for certification to the
eligibility list and promotional register, to the appeal process which may be filed by an officer or firefighter as a result
of a suspension, demotion or termination imposed by the city manager and to the appeal process arising out of
complaints brought against a member of the police or fire department by a member of the public. (Ord. 2008-10)
C. Limitation Of Rules: No governing rule of the board shall apply to the operation of the police or fire departments or the
conduct of its members. (1998 Code)
D. Examination Process: The board of fire and police commissioners shall have the authority to promulgate rules
governing the examination process for original appointment and promotion in the classified service of the fire and
police departments. (Ord. 96-44)
1-14G-7: ANNUAL REPORT:
The board shall provide to the mayor an annual report of its activities and of the rules in force and the practical effect
thereof. (1998 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=470 65/923
1-14G-8: SECRETARY:
The deputy city clerk shall serve as secretary for the board and shall keep the minutes of the board's proceedings, shall
be the custodian of all records pertaining to the business of the board, and shall keep a record of all examinations held.
(1998 Code)
1-14G-9: FACILITIES AND FUNDS:
The city shall allow reasonable use of public buildings for meetings and for the holding of examinations and shall provide
adequate funds in the annual appropriation for the operation of the board. (1998 Code)
1-14G-10: ATTORNEY FOR THE BOARD:
The city attorney shall represent the board and handle all matters before the board upon behalf of the city. In the event
that the city attorney shall represent the board, the city may employ an attorney of its choosing to serve as prosecutor
before the board. (1998 Code)
1-14G-11: APPLICATION PROCESS:
A. Application Cards: Application cards for positions in the police or fire department shall be available in the city clerk's
office. Completed cards shall be kept on file pending publication of the test date. Upon publication of the test date,
the clerk shall notify, by mail, those persons who have completed an application card that an application form will be
available in the clerk's office during regular business hours.
B. Time Qualification; Preemployment Agreement: Applications for positions in the police or fire departments shall
consist of a completed application form, provided by the city. Applications shall be submitted to the city clerk's office
by the deadline determined by the board with respect to each examination. Such dates shall be included in
publication of the examination notice. In addition, each person submitting an application shall submit a signed
preemployment agreement on the form provided by the city clerk.
C. Informational Booklet: Upon submission of a completed application form and the signed preemployment agreement,
each applicant shall receive a written explanation of the testing procedures for original appointment to the police or
fire department. (1998 Code)
1-14G-12: APPOINTMENTS:
A. Appointments By City Manager: Board, upon compilation of an eligibility list for original appointment to either the fire
department or police department, shall deliver to the city manager an alphabetical list of names of all qualified and
eligible persons for the positions. The city manager shall make all original appointments to the fire and police
departments from the list of eligible candidates. Any certificate of appointment issued shall be signed by the city
manager.
B. Appointments Discretionary: The board, upon certifying that applicants under this article have satisfied all
requirements imposed by the board, shall deliver to the city manager analphabetical list of names of all qualified and
eligible persons for reappointment to the police department or fire department. The city manager may, at his
discretion, make appointments to the police department or fire department from the respective lists of eligible
candidates for reappointment. The city manager shall sign any reappointment. (Ord. 91-53)
1-14G-13: PROMOTIONAL APPOINTMENT:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=470 66/923
A. The board, upon completion of an eligibility register for promotional appointments to either the fire department or
police department, shall deliver to the city manager an alphabetical list of the names of all qualified and eligible
people for said positions. The city manager shall make all promotional appointments to the fire and police
departments from the list of eligible candidates. Any certificate of appointment issued to any officer or member of the
fire or police department shall be signed by the city manager.
B. If a candidate does not wish to be certified as one of the eligible candidates for promotion, then his name will be
dropped from the eligibility list or if the certified letter is returned from the post office as undeliverable, then the board
of fire and police commissioners will remove the name of the uninterested or unavailable candidate from the eligibility
list. (Ord. 90-102)
1-14G-14: REVIEW OF DISCIPLINARY ACTION:
A. Appeals Board: The board has no authority in disciplinary matters involving police officers and firefighters other than
to serve as an appeal board from any disciplinary action taken by the city manager.
B. Criteria For Appeal: Any police officer or firefighter, who has been suspended, demoted or terminated by action of the
city manager, may appeal that action to the board.
C. Decision: The board is hereby granted the authority to affirm, modify, or reverse the city manager's decision. The city
manager may appeal any decision of the board to reverse his decision to the circuit court pursuant to the
administrative review act.
D. Time Limited Suspension: Nothing in this section shall be construed to prevent the city manager from suspending,
with or without pay, an officer or firefighter for a period of not more than thirty (30) days. Any police officer or
firefighter so suspended may appeal for review to the city manager within twenty four (24) hours of the notice of the
suspension, and upon appeal, the city manager may conduct a hearing. The decision of the city manager shall be
appealable to the board. The burden to show that the suspension is erroneous is upon the individual bringing the
appeal. (1998 Code)
1-14G-15: APPLICATION OF ARTICLE:
The provisions of this article pertaining to disciplinary action shall apply only to full time firefighters and full time police
officers of a regularly constituted fire or police department, who hold the rank of patrol officer or firefighter, and not to any
other personnel of the city or the police or fire chief. (1998 Code)
ARTICLE H. CARBONDALE OFFICE OF EMERGENCY
MANAGEMENT
1-14H-1: PURPOSE:
It is the declared purpose of this article to provide for the preparation and implementation of plans for the protection of
persons and property within the city in the event of a civil emergency; the direction of the Carbondale office of
emergency management; the coordination of the Carbondale office of emergency management with all other public
agencies, corporation, organizations and affected private persons. This article will assure the general well being of the
people of Carbondale. (Ord. 2015-32)
1-14H-2: DEFINITION:
As used in this article, "civil emergency" shall mean the actual or threatened existence of conditions of peril to the safety
of persons and property resulting from any natural or manmade cause, including, but not limited to, fire, flood,
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=470 67/923
earthquake, wind, storm, toxic spill, or water contamination requiring emergency action to avert danger, damage,
epidemic, air contamination, blight, drought, infestation, explosion, riot, or critical shortages of essential fuels and energy.
(Ord. 2015-32)
1-14H-3: ESTABLISHMENT:
There is hereby created the Carbondale office of emergency management (COEM) to ensure that the city will be
prepared to deal with any civil emergency and protect the public peace, health, and safety in the event of such a
disaster. (Ord. 2015-32)
1-14H-4: COORDINATOR:
The COEM shall consist of the coordinator who shall be appointed by the city manager and such other employees as
may be determined by the coordinator with the approval of the city manager. In the event of the absence of the
coordinator, the city manager, or his designee, shall act as coordinator until a new appointment is made. (Ord. 2015-32)
1-14H-5: FUNCTIONS, DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES:
The coordinator of COEM shall have the following duties and responsibilities and perform the following functions:
A. Prepare and distribute a clear and complete statement of the emergency disaster plan for the city which shall conform
to the Illinois emergency management agency and regulations which may be promulgated by the governor. In
