DRIVER: Any person who owns, drives or keeps a vehicle used for transporting "offensive substances" as defined in this
Section.
OFFENSIVE SUBSTANCES: Carcasses of any animal, or any parts thereof, offal, filth or noisome substances.
VEHICLE: Shall include only those automobiles, trucks, trailers and wagons used for transporting or hauling offensive
substances. (Ord. 969 § 1)
17-4-2: CONSTRUCTION:
The bodies of all vehicles transporting or hauling offensive substances in or through the City shall be completely covered
with a solid material or with canvass or a tarpaulin and the covering shall be constructed, secured and maintained in a
manner that will not allow flies to enter or leave the bodies thereof; the bottom or bed of all such vehicles shall be
watertight. (1998 Code)
17-4-3: CLEANLINESS REQUIRED:
All vehicles used as set out in the preceding Section shall be kept and maintained by the driver thereof in a reasonably
clean and sanitary condition. Both the interior and exterior of such vehicles shall be kept free from accumulations of
offensive substances. (Ord. 969 § 3)
17-4-4: STOPPING IN CITY LIMITS; VEHICLE COVER REQUIRED:
No vehicles used as set out in Section 17-4-2 of this Chapter shall stop or park within the City limits while transporting
offensive substances, except in cases of emergency or in order to abide by traffic laws and regulations, and while in the
Citylimits, the bodies of such vehicles shall be kept covered completely at all times. (1998 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=470 698/923
17-4-5: RIGHT TO DETAIN FOR INSPECTION:
The police officers of the City and any representative of the County Health Department are hereby authorized to stop
and detain any vehicle transporting offensive substances in the City for the purpose of inspecting the same and to
ascertain if the provisions of this Chapter are being complied with. (Ord. 969 § 5)
Chapter 5
RESPONSIBILITY FOR SIDEWALK MAINTENANCE AND
CONSTRUCTION
17-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
CAPITAL IMPROVEMENTS COMMITTEE: A Committee made up of City of Carbondale department heads.
CARBONDALE SAFETY COMMISSION: An advisory committee created by City of Carbondale ordinance.
DIRECTOR: The Director of Public Works, or any other City employee designated by the City Manager.
PARKWAY: That portion of the street between the curb line or the lateral lines of an improved roadway,and the adjacent
sidewalk or public way.
PERSON: Shall include persons, partnerships, corporations, or other business associates, and land trusts, both singular
and plural.
PUBLIC WAY: That portion of the street between the curb line or the lateral line of an improved roadway, and the
adjacent property or right-of-way line, intended for the use of pedestrians and as yet unimproved for such purpose.
SIDEWALK: That portion of the street between the curb line or the lateral line of an improved roadway, and the adjacent
property or right-of-way line, intended for the use of pedestrian and improved for such purpose. (Ord. 76-1)
17-5-2: DUTIES OF PROPERTY OWNER:
Any person owning any lot or parcel of land, whether such lot or parcel of land is improved, unimproved, occupied or
vacant, abutting on any street, avenue, parkway, boulevard, or other public street of the City, is hereby required to:
A. Sidewalks:
1. Construct and install a sidewalk in accordance with the provisions of this Chapter.
2. Keep clean and open for public passage, any sidewalk or sidewalks abutting on or adjacent to such lot or parcel of
land, and to keep such sidewalk or sidewalks in good repair and good condition in accordance with the provisions
of this Chapter.
B. Maintenance Of Parkway And Public Way:
1. To maintain the public way in a safe condition for pedestrians, free of all obstructions, excavations, tall grass,
weeks, bushes, trees, trash, debris or other substances or materials which may interfere with the free use of such
passageways by the public; except for those obstructions or ditches which have storm drainage, public utility or
other public purpose.
2. To maintain the parkway in a safe condition for pedestrians, free of all obstructions, excavations, tall grass, weeds,
bushes, trees, trash, debris or other substances or materials which may interfere with the free use of such
passageways by the public; except for those obstructions or ditches which have been constructed by the City, or
under authority granted by the City, for storm drainage, public utility or other public purposes. (Ord. 76-1)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=470 699/923
17-5-3: SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION, REPLACEMENT AND REPAIR:
A. License And Permit Required: No person shall construct, install, or repair any sidewalk within the City limits unless
such person has first obtained:
1. A sidewalk contractor's license as required by the provisions of this Chapter; and
2. A permit from the Director for such construction, installation, or repair, in accordance with the provisions of this
Chapter.
B. Responsibility Of Director: The Director is hereby authorized and made responsible for planning and programming,
construction, replacement, or repair of sidewalks using the following guidelines as a basis for establishing
procedures:
1. New Construction: General priority for sidewalk construction shall be based on the following procedures: (Ord. 90-
95)
a. Street Section Traffic Flow Classification: Each street section classified as arterial (i.e., 8,000 or more cars per
day) still receive nine (9) points. Each street section classified as collector (i.e., 1,500 to 7,999 cars per day) shall
receive six (6) points. Each street section with four hundred (400) or more cars per day but less than one
thousand five hundred (1,500) cars per day shall receive three (3) points. Each street with lessthan four hundred
(400) cars per day shall receive zero points. (Ord. 90-95; 1998 Code)
b. Snow Route Classification: Each street section on an emergency snow route as designated in subsection 18-12-
3F of this City Code of ordinances shall receive five (5) points. Each street section on a secondary snow route as
designated in subsection 18-12-3G of this City Code of ordinances, shall receive three (3) points. Each street
section not on a designated snow route shall receive zero points. (Ord. 90-95)
c. Proximity To School Classification: Each street section within one-fourth (1/4) mile of a grade or high school shall
receive five (5) points. Each street section not within one-fourth (1/4) mile of a grade or high school shall receive
zero points.
d. Adjustment Of Number Of Sides Missing Sidewalks: The points from subsections B1a, B1b, and B1c above shall
be added together for each street segment and then multiplied by the number of sides of the street segment
missing sidewalks.
e. Rank Order To Be Established: All the street segments with three (3) or more points as a result of the procedure
in subsection A1a, A1b, A1c, and A1d above shall be placed in rank order from highest number of points to
lowest number of points. This order shall set the priority for new sidewalk construction.
2. Replacement Or Repair: When the Director becomes aware of locations where existing sidewalks are broken,
have sections of different height, or other defects such that travelling on the sidewalk presents a hazard under
normal weather conditions, the Director shall determine these sections to have priority comparable to that of the
street sections rated highest under the new construction property criteria established above.
C. Other Factors: In proposing sidewalk construction programs, the Director shall primarily consider the ranking
developed from subsection B above. However, the Director shall also take into consideration other factors including
but not limited to:
1. Absence of curbs and gutters and storm sewers.
2. Accident rate.
3. Pedestrian traffic volumes.
4. Available right of way.
5. Existence of steep grades or high banks.
In the event that a physical problem such as absence of curbs and gutters and storm sewers, available right of
way, and/or existence of steep grades or high banks set forth above precludes prompt implementation of a
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=470 700/923
sidewalk project on a street section having high priority based on the criteria in subsection 17-5-3C of this City
Code, theDirector shall identify the impediment and advise the City Manager and the City Council of the necessary
actions needed to make a sidewalk physically feasible and the estimated costs therefore. (Ord. 80-20)
D. Adoption Of Ordinance: Following determination by the City Council that sidewalk construction, repair and
replacement is required in accordance with the above, they may adopt an ordinance providing for said work to be
done and financed as provided by chapter 65, article 11, division 84 of the Illinois Compiled Statutes. (Ord. 90-95)
E. Requirements In Conjunction With Building Permits:
1. Before a building permit is issued for a structure including mobile homes served by permanent water and sewer by
permanent water and sewer connections on a lot or tract having no abutting sidewalks where said lot or tract would
receive three (3) or more points on the rating system set forth in subsection B of this Section, the owner of such lot
or tract shall agree to install sidewalks on the side of all streets abutting such lot or tract that would have the
aforesaid three (3) or more points, not including, for corner lots, sidewalk extensions up to the curb line at the
nearest street intersection.
2. Construction of a sidewalk at any point may be deferred by execution of a signed agreement between the Director
and the owner or developer when the Director finds that it is unreasonable to construct sidewalks because of the
cost involved, taking into consideration the following factors: cost of engineering, cost of construction, need for
sidewalks, and the topographic condition of the terrain where the sidewalk would be constructed. Any such
agreement shall stipulate the terms and conditions under which such deferment shall terminate.
3. Before an occupancy permit is issued for structures described in subsection E1 above, the owner of the lot or tract
shall have had installed sidewalks on the side of all streets abutting such lot or tract that would have the aforesaid
three (3) or more points, not including, for corner lots, sidewalk extensions up to the curb line at the nearest street
intersection, unless subsection E2 above is applicable and a signed agreement between the Director and the
owner or developer has been properly executed. (Ord. 80-20)
17-5-4: SIDEWALK CONTRACTOR'S LICENSE AND SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION PERMIT:
A. License Required: It shall be unlawful for a sidewalk to be constructed, replaced or repaired by any person unless he
shall possess a valid sidewalk contractor's license issued by the City Clerk, except as provided below. An application
for said license shall be made to the Director and shall include such information as shall be determined to be
necessary by the Director,including, but not limited to, the following:
1. Name and address of person and, in the case of any corporate applicant, names and addresses of the officers of
the corporation;
2. Names and addresses of the person or persons who will be responsible for the actual construction, replacement or
repair to be performed; and
3. Evidence that said persons are familiar with and agree to abide by the provisions of this Chapter and the
specifications adopted pursuant thereto.
Provided the owner of property or his tenant may construct, replace or repair a sidewalk adjacent to said property,
to a maximum quantity of fifty (50) square feet per year, without obtaining a sidewalk contractor's license, provided
all other provisions of this Chapter, including the obtaining of a permit, are complied with any provided further that
said person does the work personally. (Ord. 90-95)
B. License Revocation: Upon recommendation by the Director, and subject to a written appeal to City Council submitted
to the City Clerk within five (5) days of same, the City Manager can revoke, for cause, a sidewalk contractor's license
granted under the authority of this Chapter. Notice of revocation may be served in person or mailed by certified mail
to the last known address of the firm or its owner. Evidence of any violation of this Chapter shall be sufficient cause
for revocation.
C. License Fee: The fee for a sidewalk contractor's license, for all or any part of a year, shall be twenty five dollars
($25.00). All said licenses shall expire on April 30 of each year.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=470 701/923
D. Permit Required: It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, replace, or repair, or cause to be constructed,
replaced or repaired by contract, any sidewalk, or to begin excavation for the construction, replacement or repair of
any sidewalk, without first obtaining from the Director a permit in writing to do so. No fee shall be charged for said
permit. The permit application shall contain the following information which shall be attested to by the owner or his
agent so authorized in writing:
1. Street address of property in question, or in absence of any assigned street number, the legal description of the
property adjacent to the street right of way in which construction is to take place;
2. Name and address of property owner;
3. Name, address and license number of licensed sidewalk contractor who will perform work;
4. Description of a related construction work, including buildingpermit number, planned as part of same project on the
owner's adjacent property;
5. Evidence that the proper grade for the sidewalk has either been determined and made available to the contractor
by the Director, or that he has approved the surface grade of construction proposed by the owner or contractor;
6. Evidence that the contractor and/or owner is familiar with all the provisions of this Chapter and the construction
specifications adopted pursuant thereto and agrees to abide thereby.
All work for which a permit is issued shall be completed and accepted by the Director within forty five (45) days of
the date of issuance, otherwise the permit shall be considered null and void. Where justified by reason of related
work or for other good or sufficient reasons, this time period may be extended by the Director, either at the time of
issuance or as an extension granted prior to said time of expiration.
E. Inspections Required: The Director or his authorized representative shall inspect the work to be performed under each
sidewalk permit as follows:
1. After submission of permit application and prior to issuance;
2. After completion of all cut, fill, grading and placement of forms, and prior to the pouring of any concrete; and
3. Following certification by the owner or contractor that the work has been satisfactorily completed in accordance
with the provisions of the permit and this Chapter.
Any person to whom a permit has been issued must obtain written approval to proceed from the Director or an
authorized inspector prior to further work being done or the permit marked completed and the work accepted by the
City. (Ord. 76-1)
17-5-5: FINANCE SCHEDULE:
A. Sidewalk Constructed After January 13, 1976: Any sidewalk constructed after January 13, 1976, shall be financed
entirely by the owner of the abutting or adjacent property to such a sidewalk, except that the City shall bear the
expense of all engineering, establishing of grades, construction of extensions of public walks to the curb line at corner
lots, and other costs not normally associated with the construction of sidewalks along an improved street as may be
recommended by the Director and approved by City Council. Provided, however, that the construction of sidewalks in
tracts of land being subdivided or on unimproved streets which are being improved by the abutting property owner
with approval of the City, shall in all instances be completely financed by the person owning such propertyincluding all
engineering and other incidental expenses, except as may be agreed to otherwise by action of the City Council.
B. Sidewalks For Platted Corner Lots: Notwithstanding the provisions of this Chapter, at such time as sidewalk
construction shall be required, under Sec. 17-5-3 of this Chapter, on both sides of any platted corner lot, the City shall
be responsible for paying fifty percent (50%) of the costs of construction incurred on both sides of such corner lot,
except if the corner lot is: 1) zoned or used for commercial purposes, or 2) in a tract of land being subdivided or
abutting an unimproved street, the City shall not be responsible for paying any such costs.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=470 702/923
C. Replacement Or Repair Of Sidewalk: The cost of sidewalk replacement or repair shall be paid entirely by the City, if
the Director or his designee determines that the sidewalk in question qualifies under the City's replacement program.
This determination shall be based on a point system established by the Director or his designee. If the sidewalk in
question does not qualify under the City's replacement program, but is in need of replacement or repair, and if the
property owner requests, in writing, that the sidewalk in question be replaced or repaired, then the City and the
property owner shall share equally the cost to replace the sidewalk. In no case shall the City share in the cost of
replacement or repair of the sidewalk where the request for the City participation is not made in writing prior to the
performance of the replacement or repair work and where the request has not been approved by the Director or his
designee. The Director or his designee may grant approval of such request after determining that:
1. The work is justified on the basis of City specifications and accepted engineering and safety standards;
2. The width and length of work to be performed is justified on the same basis; and
3. The cost of the work is in conformity with recent costs paid by the City for similar work. Should the Director
determine that the above criteria are not fully substantiated, he may adjust the amount of the City's participation as
is needed for conformity. (Ord. 90-95)
17-5-6: DESIGN CRITERIA:
Specifications for construction, replacement and repair of sidewalks shall adhere to the following standards, except as
noted.
A. Width Of Sidewalks: All sidewalks shall be constructed to a minimum width of four feet (4'0"), except where the
volume of pedestrian traffic justifies a greater width, the Director may require a greater width to provide for such
condition. Upon such ruling by the Director, the person owning the abutting property may petition the City Council for
the City to pay for the cost ofconstruction of said additional width unless the use to which the property is being put
substantially contributes to the need for extra width.
B. Location: All sidewalks shall be located such that the edge of the walk is one foot (1'0") from the street right-of-way
line, entirely on street right of way, unless the Director authorizes in writing an alternate location do to inadequate
right-of-way width, grade conditions, and location of ditches or other physical features which cannot be feasibly
altered.
C. Slope: All sidewalks shall be constructed with a minimum slope towards the street of one-fourth inch (1/4") per foot of
width, and a maximum longitudinal grade of six percent (6%) except where a greater longitudinal grade may be
authorized in writing by the Director.
D. Integrity And Permanence Preserved: All sidewalks shall be constructed such as to preserve their integrity and
permanence; and, new sidewalks or sidewalk replacements, when built as part of the same project as driveways or
parking areas, shall be defined by construction or expansion joints, as determined to be necessary by the Director,
and shall be continuous through asphalt paved areas; and, when sidewalks are constructed upon property which is
paved other than with Portland cement paving, said new sidewalks shall be constructed continuously through said
existing paving and shall be constructed with Portland cement paving.
E. Detailed Specifications: Detailed specifications for the construction of sidewalks shall be developed by the Director in
booklet form and, upon adoption by resolution by the City Council, shall be in effect from and after date of adoption.
Any violation of said specifications, following adoption by Council, shall constitute a violation of the provisions of this
Chapter and the penalty provisions provided therefor.
F. Temporary Walkway: In situations where physical conditions make construction of new sidewalks to adopted
standards impractical, or where new street or other construction is anticipated which would cause a basic change to
the location of a needed sidewalk, the Director may cause to be constructed at City expense or upon agreement at
the owner's expense, a temporary walkway. Said temporary walk may be constructed of such materials and to such
standards as the Director shall determine to meet both safety and economic conditions within the projected timetable
for permanent sidewalk construction. (1998 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=470 703/923
17-5-7: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this Chapter shall be subject to a fine not to exceed seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00). Each day's violation of the provisions of this Chapter shall be deemed a separate offense, and shall be
punishable as provided in this Section. (Ord. 90-95; Ord. 97-166; 1998 Code)
17-5-8: FINANCIAL HARDSHIP PETITIONS:
A. Any person who is aggrieved by the application of the sidewalk article by reason of being financially unable to pay the
special tax for sidewalk construction or repair shall file a petition in such form as the City Treasurer may require fully
setting forth the hardship grounds on which the petitioner relies.
B. All petitions shall be filed with the City Treasurer on or before April 1 of the year during which the first installment of a
special tax becomes due. No petition shall be filed after such time.
C. The City Treasurer shall review all petitions properly filed no later than June 15 and shall immediately thereafter report
its recommendations to the City Council stating their reasons for their recommendation in their report.
D. If the City Treasurer denies a request, he shall, within two (2) weeks thereof, forward said request. If the request is
granted, the City Treasurer shall refrain from reporting the unpaid tax to the County Collector; however, no unpaid tax
shall go unreported to the County Recorder of Deeds for the purpose of recording with the County the City's tax lien
against the property. No unpaid tax shall go unreported to the County Collector indefinitely. The Treasurer shall
review any hardship petition granted every two (2) years on or about April 15 to determine the status of the case and
to report the Treasurer's findings to the City Council on or about the June 15 following their review. The City Council
shall, within two (2) weeks, direct the Treasurer to report or to refrain from reporting the unpaid tax to the County
Collector. (Ord. 75-24)
Chapter 6
SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION
17-6-1: CONCRETE CONSTRUCTION REQUIRED:
All sidewalks along or upon any street or part of a street or alley shall be made of Portland cement concrete. (Ord. 690
§ 1)
17-6-2: MANNER OF CONSTRUCTION ASCERTAINED FROM ORDINANCE:
Sidewalks shall be constructed in the manner specifically provided in the ordinance fixing the location, dimension and
grade thereof. (Ord. 690 § 1)
17-6-3: RELATION TO STREET RIGHT-OF-WAY LINE:
All sidewalks shall be located such that the edge of the walk is one foot (1') from the street right-of-way line, entirely on
street right of way, unless the Director authorizes in writing an alternate location due to inadequate right-of-way width,
grade conditions, the location of ditches or other physical features which cannot be feasibly altered. (Ord. 1514 § 7B)
17-6-4: THICKNESS AND WIDTH:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=470 704/923
A. Sidewalks: All sidewalks shall be not less than four inches (4") in thickness. All sidewalks shall be constructed to a
minimum width of four feet nine inches (4'9") except where the volume of pedestrian traffic justifies a greater width,
the Director of Public Works may require a greater width to provide for such condition. Upon such ruling by the
Director, the person owning the abutting property may petition the City Council for the City to pay for the cost of
construction of said additional width unless the use to which the property is being put substantially contributes to the
need for the extra width. (Ord. 690 § 2; Ord. 1514 § 7A)
B. Crosswalks: All crosswalks shall be not less than five inches (5") thick and of the same width of connecting walks.
(Ord. 690 § 2)
17-6-5: SURFACE ROUGHENED:
On all grades exceeding five percent (5%) the surface of finished walks and crosswalks shall be roughened with a brush,
toothed roller or other suitable tool. (Ord. 690 § 2)
17-6-6: SLOPE:
All sidewalks shall be constructed with a minimum slope towards the street of one-fourth inch (1/4") per foot of width, and
a maximum longitudinal grade of six percent (6%) except where a greater longitudinal grade may be authorized in writing
by the Director. (Ord. 1514 § 7C)
17-6-7: CROSS DRAINAGE:
A. Required: At the ends of all crosswalks on unpaved streets, and at other points along the sidewalks where the
watercourses or surface drains of any kind cross the line of the proposed sidewalks, cross drainage shall be
provided.
B. Type And Size Of Pipe: The cross drainage required by the preceding subsection shall consist of hard burned, salt
glazed, vitrified clay, sewer pipe of sufficient size in each individual case to readily carry the water naturally reaching
them.
C. Length And Placement Of Pipes: The pipes referred to in thepreceding subsection shall be of sufficient length to
extend not less than one foot (1') on either side of the sidewalk under which they are placed and shall in general be
placed so that their upper sides are below the bottom of the concrete walk. (Ord. 690 § 3)
17-6-8: SUBGRADE:
That portion of the streets and alleys to be covered with sidewalks and crosswalks shall be brought to a subgrade by
excavating or filling, as the case may be, the cross section to conform in every respect to the cross section of the walks
when completed, and the upper surface shall be parallel with and below the surface of the finished walk, a distance
equal to the thickness of the walk. Whenever soft clay or spongy ground is developed in the subgrade that will not
compact under the roller or tamper, it shall be removed and the excavation filled with suitable dry earth before the
concrete is placed. All subgrades shall be thoroughly rolled or properly tamped by hand before the concrete is laid
thereon. When a fill exceeding one foot (1') in thickness is required, it shall be thoroughly compacted by flooding, rolling
or tamping in layers not exceeding six inches (6") in thickness and shall have a side slope of not less than one vertical to
one and one-half horizontal (1:11/2). The top of all fills shall extend at least twelve inches (12") on either side of the walk
to be constructed thereon. While compacting, the subgrade shall be thoroughly wetted and shall be maintained in that
condition until the concrete is deposited. (Ord. 690 § 41)
17-6-9: FORMS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=470 705/923
Forms shall be of wood, free from warp and not less than one and three-fourths inches (13/4") in thickness, or metal,
firmly held to line and grade with the upper edge of the form corresponding to the finished grade of the walk. All mortar
and dirt shall be removed from forms previously used. Division lines shall be plainly marked on both side forms to locate
the position of cross forms for joints and to give the dividing line to be cut through with the groover. Metal cross forms
one-eighth (1/8) to three-sixteenths (3/16) of an inch thick shall be used to separate the blocks. They shall be cut to the
cross section of the walk and provided with a square lug on each end to fit a notch in the side forms. Cross forms shall
be set perpendicular to the surface of the walk, five feet (5') apart and at right angles to the side forms. Wooden forms
shall be wetted and metal forms shall be oiled before any concrete is deposited against them. (Ord. 690 § 5)
17-6-10: LIMITATION ON AREA OF BLOCKS:
No block of the walk shall contain more than thirty six (36) square feet. (1998 Code)
17-6-11: EXPANSION JOINTS:
Premoulded expansion joints, one-half inch (1/2") thick, of bitumen with a fibre matrix, shall be placed at intervals of not
over fifty feet (50') and at all four (4) sides of the square formed by intersecting walks, between curbs and walks, and
between sidewalks and buildings and other rigid structures. Care shall be taken to install transverse expansion joints at
right angles to side forms and perpendicular to the surface of the walk. (Ord. 690 § 5)
17-6-12: CEMENT SPECIFICATIONS AND TESTS:
A. Specifications And Tests: All cement used in the construction of sidewalks shall be Portland cement, which shall
conform to the "Standard Specifications and Test for Portland Cement of the American Society for Testing Materials,
(Serial Designation C9-25)". Samples for testing shall be furnished in such manner and at such times as required by
the City Council. The cement shall be kept dry and under cover until used and any cement exposed to the weather
after testing shall not be used. Any cement rejected by the Council after inspection shall be removed from the line of
work at once. (Ord. 690 § 6)
B. Aggregate:
1. Fine Aggregate: Fine aggregate shall consist of natural sand having clean, hard, strong, durable uncoated grains,
free from injurious amounts of dust, lumps, soft or flaky particles, shale alkali, organic matter, loam or other
deleterious substances. The sand shall be of such size that it shall all pass through a three-eighths inch (3/8")
sieve, at least fifteen percent (15%) shall be retained on the No. 8 sieve and the finest modulus shall not exceed
three and twenty one-hundredths (3.20). (1998 Code)
2. Course Aggregate: Course aggregate shall consist of gravel, crushed stone or other approved inert materials
having clean, hard, strong, durable, uncoated particles, free from injurious amounts of soft, friable, thin, elongated
or laminated prices, alkali, organic or other deleterious matter. Course aggregate shall have not more than ten
percent (10%) finer than the No. 4 sieve and the maximum size shall not exceed three-fourths of an inch (3/4").
Aggregate shall be stored to avoid inclusion of foreign materials. Frozen aggregate or aggregate containing lumps
of frozen materials shall be thawed before using. (Ord. 690 § 6)
17-6-13: WATER FOR CONCRETE:
Water for concrete shall be from the City water supply or other approved source. (Ord. 690 § 6)
17-6-14: GRADES AND LINES:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=470 706/923
A. Conform To Ordinance: All work during its progress and upon its completion shall conform truly to the lines and
grades for the work to be established by ordinance.
B. Conform To Profile: The top of the sidewalk grade edge, being the inner or property line edge of the walk, shall be as
shown on the profile therefor. The elevations given thereon shall be measured in feet and decimal parts thereof
above the datum plane of the City.
C. Grade Changes: At all points where there is a sharp change of grade, the grades shall be connected by a vertical
curve, but in no case shall the length of the curve exceed one hundred feet (100') or its middle ordinate exceed eight
inches (8").
D. Adjustment Of Grades To Existing Walks: All grades shall be adjusted to existing concrete walks to allow smooth and
even passage from the new to the old work. (Ord. 690 § 7)
17-6-15: MIXING OF CONCRETE:
A. Proportions: The concrete shall be mixed in the proportions by volume of one part Portland cement, two (2) parts fine
aggregate and three (3) parts course aggregate.
B. Measuring Area Of Bagged Cement: One sack of cement (94 pounds net) shall be considered one cubic foot.
C. Ratio Of Water To Cement: Water for mixing sidewalk cement shall not exceed six and one-fourth (61/4) gallons per
cubic foot of cement.
D. Measurement Of Materials: All sidewalk ingredients including water shall be accurately measured.
E. Use Of Approved Batch Mixer Required: All ingredients for preparing sidewalks shall be mixed in an approved batch
mixer not less than one minute after all materials are in the drum. (Ord. 690 § 9)
17-6-16: PATTING CONCRETE IN PLACE:
In laying sidewalks, the subgrade shall be wetted and the concrete deposited the full length and width of the forms.
Concrete shall be handled from the mixer to place as rapidly as practicable and in a manner that will prevent segregation
of the ingredients. It shall be deposited in the forms as nearly as practicable in its final position to avoid rehandling. (Ord.
690 § 9)
17-6-17: PUDDLING; CONSISTENCY OF CONCRETE:
Concrete as it is deposited shall be puddled with suitable toolsuntil forms are completely filled. The consistency of the
concrete shall be such that it can be puddled into the corners and angles of forms without excessive spading and without
segregation or excess accumulation of water or laitance on the surface. (Ord. 690 § 9)
17-6-18: TAMPING AND STRIKING OFF:
After tamping, the concrete shall be struck off with a template riding on the side forms. (Ord. 690 § 9)
17-6-19: FINISHING:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=470 707/923
The surface shall be finished with a wooden float, leveling off any high sports and filling depressions and working excess
water over the side forms after which it shall be carefully checked with a straight edge. The edges at joints and sides
shall be rounded with a edger having a radius of one-fourth of an inch (1/4"). (Ord. 690 § 9)
17-6-20: CROSSWALKS:
A. Location Of Crosswalks: At all places where the walks intersect unpaved roads, streets or alleys, crosswalks shall be
constructed instead of the ordinary sidewalks.
B. Extent Of Crosswalks: Crosswalks shall extend across the entire width of all alleys and from curb line edge to curb
line edge across all roads and streets, the curb line edge referred to being the outer or road side edge of the walks on
either side of the street. (Ord. 690 § 9)
17-6-21: CONSTRUCTION OF OWN WALKS BY PROPERTY OWNERS:
If a property owner shall desire to construct his own sidewalk, and if at the time such property is not included in any
proposed sidewalk improvement district, such property owner shall first secure the services of the Director of Public
Works in establishing the grade of such sidewalk. All such work shall be done under the supervision of the Director of
Public Works, unless specific direction to the contrary is made by the City Council. (Ord. 690 § 8; Ord. 1504 Art. V § 3)
17-6-22: STREET DIRT:
In the work of construction of sidewalks and crosswalks where it is necessary to make a fill in the preparation of the
subgrade or sub-base, in no instance shall the dirt be removed from any part of the street or alley and used in making
such fill for subgrade. (Ord. 690 § 10)
17-6-23: DIRT FROM LINE OF WALK:
Dirt taken out of the line of the walks to be constructed where a cut is necessary may be used in cases of fills for
subgrade. (Ord. 690 § 10)
17-6-24: FREEZING WEATHER:
In freezing weather, suitable means shall be provided for maintaining the concrete at a temperature of at least fifty
degrees Fahrenheit (50°F) for seventy two (72) hours or more after placing or until the concrete has thoroughly
hardened. The methods of heating the materials and protecting the concrete shall be approved by the City Council. Salt,
chemicals or other foreign materials shall not be mixed with the concrete for the purpose of preventing freezing. No
concrete shall be deposited upon a frozen subgrade. (Ord. 690 § 10)
17-6-25: PROTECTING CONCRETE WHILE SETTING:
A. Covered And Kept Wet: Immediately after the surface of a concrete walk is finished and the concrete has set
sufficiently to prevent marring, it shall be covered with burlap or canvas and kept wet by sprinkling for at least seven
(7) days.
B. Wheeled Traffic Prohibited: No walk or crosswalk shall be subjected to wheeled traffic for at least fourteen (14) days.
(Ord. 690 § 10)
17-6-26: REMOVAL OF FORMS; BANKING NEW WALKS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=470 708/923
After a concrete walk has set sufficiently, side forms shall be carefully removed and the earth shall be graded up against
the edges of the sidewalks and crosswalks. (Ord. 690 § 10)
17-6-27: TEMPERATURE OF CONCRETE WHEN DEPOSITED:
Concrete when deposited to make a walk shall have a temperature of not less than fifty degrees Fahrenheit (50°F) and
not more than ninety degrees Fahrenheit (90°F). (Ord. 690 § 10; 1998 Code)
17-6-28: REMOVAL OF FLOAT MARKS:
Float marks shall be removed from new concrete walks by brushing the surface with a soft bristled brush. (Ord. 690
§ 10)
17-6-29: PROTECTION OF WALK WHEN WORK SUSPENDED; REMOVAL OF EXCESS
CONCRETE:
When work on a concrete walk is suspended, a bulkhead shall beplaced at right angles to the side forms and
perpendicular to the surface at the end of the slab to form a vertical joint. Any excess of concrete shall be removed from
the subgrade before starting work. (Ord. 690 § 10)
17-6-30: DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC WORKS TO DIRECT ALL WORK:
The work on walks shall, at all times, be under the direction of the Director of Public Works, unless specific direction to
the contrary is made by the City Council. (Ord. 1504 Art. V § 3)
17-6-31: STANDARDS OF WORK GENERALLY:
All work on walks shall be done in a thorough and workmanlike manner to the satisfaction of the Council. (Ord. 690 § 11)
17-6-32: PROTECTION OF WORK IN PROGRESS:
During the progress of work, walks shall be properly barricaded and protected against injury. (Ord. 690 § 11)
17-6-33: CONTRACTOR TO BEAR LOSS FROM INJURY:
The contractor shall bear all loss from injured walks under construction. (Ord. 690 § 11)
Chapter 7
PROCEDURE FOR EXTENSION OF STREET SYSTEM
17-7-1: PURPOSE:
It is the purpose and intent of this chapter to establish policy and procedure for the extension and improvement, through
construction and reconstruction, of the street system of the city by the cooperation and participation of the city and
abutting property owners. (Ord. 73-9 § 1)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=470 709/923
17-7-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms and words shall have the meanings opposite them:
AVENUE: Shall be synonymous with street for the purpose of this chapter.
COLLECTOR STREET: Any street that is designed to provide for a flow of traffic from several minor streets to a major
street.
CUL-DE-SAC: A street having one open end and being permanently terminated by a vehicle turnaround at the other end.
FORCE ACCOUNT: Work performed by city work crews.
FRONTAGE ROAD: A public or private marginal access roadway or paved parking lot containing necessary driveways or
trafficways located along the frontage of a multiple family, business or industrial zoning district which have regulations
pursuant to the zoning ordinance or other ordinances of the city of Carbondale for establishing minimum distance points
of access to the street and the elimination of parking of automobiles on such streets.
LOCAL STREET: A street intended primarily as access to abutting properties. (Local street as defined in this chapter is
not to be confused with local street as defined in section 17-8-2 of this title.)
MAJOR STREET: A street designed for heavy traffic and of considerable continuity and used primarily as a traffic artery
for intercommunication between communities in the vicinity of the city.
SECONDARY STREET: A street or road located outside the city limits of the city of Carbondale. ("Secondary street" as
defined in this chapter is not to be confused with "secondary street" as defined in section 17-8-2 of this title.)
STREET: The public street right of way or easement. (Ord. 73-9 § 2)
17-7-3: LIMITATIONS:
A. The procedure established in this chapter is applicable to the construction and reconstruction only of collector streets,
cul-de-sacs, and local streets, which shall be referred to henceforth in this chapter as street. (Ord. 73-9 § 3)
B. The procedure for the construction or reconstruction of streets as set forth in this chapter does not apply to
subdividers and developers, or those engaged in the subdivision or development of new housing units within or
outside the corporate limits of the city. The construction or reconstruction of streets in newly subdivided areas shall
be controlled by the subdivision ordinance (title 15, chapter 8 of this code) of the city. (Ord. 2013-21)
17-7-4: INITIATION OF ACTION:
At the request of a citizen who owns property abutting a street in the city, or by a motion of the city council, a resolution
shall be adopted by said council establishing the area to be benefited by the proposed improvement, and establishing a
time, place and location of a public hearing to determine whether or not said improvement should be constructed. (Ord.
73-9 § 4)
17-7-5: STUDY AND NOTICE BY CITY:
After passage of the aforementioned resolution, the city shall complete the following study and serve the following notice:
A. Proposed Improvement: The city manager shall have a study made of the proposed improvement and shall have an
estimate of the proposed improvement prepared;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=470 710/923
B. Notice Of Hearing: The director of planning shall notify in writing, the owner, mortgagee or lienholder, as shown by the
land records of the recorder of deeds of the county of Jackson, of the time, date, place and purpose of the hearing.
Notice shall be served on said owner, mortgagee, or lienholder by mailing, by certified mail, said notice to the last
known address of said parties as indicated by the land records of the recorder of deeds of the county of Jackson.
Proof of mailing shall be sufficient proof of receipt of notice for the purpose of this chapter. Notice will be served upon
said parties at least fourteen (14) days prior to said hearing. (Ord. 73-9 § 5)
17-7-6: PUBLIC HEARING:
At the public hearing established by the aforementioned resolution, council will determine whether:
A. There is a need for the proposed improvement;
B. Other real property included in the benefited area is able to bear the necessary assessment, which will be made
subject to the terms of special assessments as set forth below;
C. Whether owners of fifty percent (50%) or more of the real property abutting the proposed improvements are opposed
to said improvement.
Based on these factors, council shall determine whether or not the proposed improvement should be completed.
(Ord. 73-9 § 6)
17-7-7: DETERMINATION OF COST:
If council decides that the proposed improvement should be completed, the cost thereof shall be determined as follows:
A. Force Account: If said improvement is completed by the city by force account, the cost shall be as follows: The cost of
materials used in making said improvement; plus the rental cost of the equipment used; plus the labor cost to cover
fringe benefits, administration and overhead; less the salvage value of anything removed or acquired in making said
improvement.
B. Contract: If the improvement is performed by contract with the city, the cost shall be as follows: The actual cost to the
city for all work done in the completion of said improvement. (Ord. 73-9 § 7)
17-7-8: PAYMENT OF COST:
A. Payment By City: The city shall pay:
1. Fifty percent (50%) of the cost of street base and surface;
2. One hundred percent (100%) of engineering design and inspection costs;
3. One hundred percent (100%) of the cost for storm sewers (if storm sewers are required);
4. One hundred percent (100%) of right of way acquisition (if necessary);
5. One hundred percent (100%) of any and all legal fees relating directly to said construction or reconstruction.
B. Special Assessment: A special assessment shall be applied equitably to each parcel of real property abutting the
constructed or reconstructed street based on the following costs:
1. Fifty percent (50%) of the street base and surface cost;
2. One hundred percent (100%) of the curb and gutter construction;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=470 711/923
3. One hundred percent (100%) of the sidewalk abutting costs (if required). (Ord. 73-9 § 8)
17-7-9: STANDARDS FOR CONSTRUCTION:
All construction of improvements made pursuant to this Chapter shall be built according to the standards adopted by
ordinance of the City. (Ord. 73-9 § 9)
17-7-10: NONEXCLUSIVE PROCEDURE:
The procedures for the construction or reconstruction of streets as set forth in this Chapter are not exclusive procedures.
The City Council may, at its discretion, engage in any public improvement. In any event where there is funding available
through any Federal program, the City Council may construct or reconstruct any street within the City. If such Federal
funds do not cover one hundred percent (100%) of the cost of said construction or reconstruction, the City Council may
apportion said cost between the property owner and the City as set forth in the procedures established by this Chapter.
Any construction or reconstruction or improvement of any kind decided upon pursuant to the terms and conditions of this
Chapter shall be begun and completed pursuant to a specific ordinance covering the proposed improvement. (Ord. 73-9
§ 10)
Chapter 8
STREET CONSTRUCTION AND PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS
17-8-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of Sections 17-8-1 through 17-8-8 of this Chapter shall be to provide rules, regulations and standards to
guide the proper design of public improvements in subdivisions within the City and the area contiguous to and within one
and one-half (11/2) miles of the City in order to promote the public safety, health, convenience and welfare of the citizens
of the City (Ord. 73-4 § 1)
17-8-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of Sections 17-8-1 through 17-8-8 of this Chapter, the following initials, when used herein, shall have the
following meaning:
ADT: Average daily traffic.
CBR: California bearing ratio.
IBR: Illinois bearing ratio.
LOCAL: A street being located within the City limits of the City of Carbondale.
SECONDARY: A street or road located outside the City limits of the City of Carbondale. (Ord. 73-4 § 2)
17-8-3: MINIMUM PAVEMENT WIDTHS FOR STREETS WITH CURBS AND GUTTERS:
A. One Thousand Vehicles Per Day Or Less:
1. If the current ADT at the time of the completion of the improvement on a local street, consists of one thousand
(1,000) vehicles per day or less, and there is no parking allowed on said street, the minimum width for such street
must be twenty four feet (24'), which width shall be determined by measuring from the face of the curb on one side
of the street to the face of the curb on the other side of the street.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=470 712/923
2. If the current ADT, at the time of the completion of the improvement on a local street, consists of one thousand
(1,000) vehicles per day or less, and parallel parking is allowed on one side of the street, the minimum width for
such street must be twenty eight feet (28'), which width shall be determined as set forth in subsection A1 of this
Section.
3. If the current ADT, at the time of the completion of the improvement on a local street, consists of one thousand
vehicles (1,000) vehicles per day or less, and parallel parking is allowed on both sides of the street, the minimum
width for such street must be thirty four feet (34'), which width shall be determined as set forth in subsection A1 of
this Section.
B. One Thousand To Five Thousand Vehicles Per Day:
1. If the current ADT, at the time of the completion of the improvement on a secondary street, consists of one
thousand (1,000) to five thousand (5,000) vehicles per day, and there is no parking allowed on said street, the
minimum width for such street must be twenty six feet (26'), which width shall be determined as set forth in
subsection A1 of this Section.
2. If the current ADT, at the time of the completion of the improvement on a secondary street, consists of one
thousand (1,000) to five thousand (5,000) vehicles per day, and parallel parking is allowed on one side of the
street, the minimum width for such street must be thirty feet (30'), which width shall be determined as set forth in
subsection A1 of this Section.
3. If the current ADT, at the time of the completion of the improvement on a secondary street, consists of one
thousand (1,000) to five thousand (5,000) vehicles per day, and parallel parking is allowed on both sides of the
street, the minimum width for such street must be thirty six feet (36'), which width shall be determined as set forth
in subsection A1 of this Section.
C. Five Thousand Vehicles Per Day: If the current ADT exceeds five thousand (5,000) vehicles per day, the width shall
be as set forth in State Department of Transportation Division of Highways Bureau of Design Highway Standards,
and the Department of Transportation Administrative Manual, which are hereby incorporated herein and made a part
hereof. (Ord. 73-4 § 3)
17-8-4: MINIMUM PAVEMENT THICKNESS:
A. The Manual for the Structural Design of Portland CementConcrete Pavements in Illinois, and the Manual of
Instructions for Structural Design of Bituminous Pavement on Projects Involving Motor Fuel Tax and Federal Aid
Secondary Funds, all as published by the State of Illinois Department of Transportation, Division of Highways, are
incorporated herein, made a part hereof, and are hereby adopted as the City standards for computing the minimum
pavement thickness which will be approved for any subdivision. The traffic data required for the analysis will be jointly
arrived at by the developer's engineer and the City Engineer. The CBR or IBR values required for the analysis may
be based on soil classification samples or a reasonable estimate may jointly be arrived at by the developer's engineer
and the City Engineer. The developer's engineer shall make the required computations for pavement determination
and thickness in accordance with the Manual, and the developer may choose the most economical combination
which meets all of the requirements set forth in the Manual for the class of street being designed. Any extra
requirements imposed by the City for extra thickness or width shall be paid for by the City. Any joint City/developer
project shall require an agreement approved by the City Council prior to any work being done on the project.
B. If the City Engineer and the developer's engineer are unable to agree on the CBR or IBR values, the City Engineer
and the developer's engineer shall appoint a third engineer to make soil classification and to determine the CBR or
IBR values. (1998 Code)
17-8-5: STANDARDS:
The State Department of Transportation, Division of Highways, Bureau of Design Highway Standards are incorporated
herein, made a part hereof and are hereby adopted as the City standards for streets and other public improvement. (Ord.
73-4 § 5)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=470 713/923
17-8-6: POLICIES:
The State Department of Transportation, Division of Highways, Bureau of Local Roads and Streets Administrative Policy
Manual is incorporated herein, made a part hereof, and is hereby adopted as the City policy manual on items relating to
streets, highways, and their appurtenances. (Ord. 73-4 § 6)
17-8-7: STANDARD SPECIFICATIONS FOR ROAD AND BRIDGE CONSTRUCTION:
The State Department of Transportation, Division of Highways Standards Specifications for Road and Bridge
Construction is incorporated herein, made a part hereof, and is hereby adopted as the City standards specifications for
road and bridges construction. (Ord. 73-4 § 7)
17-8-8: STANDARD SPECIFICATIONS FOR WATER AND SEWER CONSTRUCTION:
The Standard Specifications for Water and Sewer Main Construction in Illinois, published by the Illinois Society of
Professional Engineers, is incorporated herein, made a part hereof, and is hereby adopted as the City minimum
specifications for water and sewer main construction. (Ord. 73-4 § 8)
17-8-9: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Any person who constructs any public improvement or portion thereof in violation of the provisions of Sections 17-8-1
through 17-8-8 of this Chapter shall be fined not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00) for each offense deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 73-
4 § 9; Ord. 97-166; 1998 Code)
17-8-10: STREET CONSTRUCTION WHERE CURBS AND GUTTERS REQUIRED:
Where combination concrete curbs and gutters are to be constructed, the following sections of the Standard
Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction adopted January 2, 1952 by the State Department of Public Works and
Buildings, Division of Highways, and all current revisions thereto, shall apply:
Shoulders and parkways - section 24 and 26
PCC sidewalks (5" thick and 4'0" wide) section 87
Combination concrete curbs and gutters (30' from face to face of curbs) - section 81
Storm sewers Type 1 - section 68
Catch basins, manholes, inlets - section 76
Crushed stone base course Type "B", 7" in compacted thickness - section 27
Bituminous surface treatment for gravel or crushed stone bases
Class A, Sub-Class A-3 - section 35
Circular arc crown - minimum 4"
Prior to the construction of any storm sewers, a complete study of the drainage area, leading into such proposed storm
sewers, shall be made and storm sewer sizes determined.
Two (2) copies of plans of all proposed street improvements, including storm sewer design, shall be submitted to and
approved by the City prior to the beginning of any construction. (Ord. 1052 § 1)
17-8-11: STREET CONSTRUCTION; RURAL TYPE:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=470 714/923
Where the proposed street construction is to be a rural type, the following sections of the Standard Specifications for
Road and Bridge Construction adopted January 2, 1952 by the State Department of Public Works and Buildings, Division
of Highways, and all current revisions thereto shall apply:
Shoulders and parkways - section 24 and 26
Pipe culverts, Type 1 - section 59
Crushed stone base course, Type "B", 7" in compacted thickness (minimum width - 20' surface) - section 27
Prior to the installation of any pipe culverts, a complete study of the drainage area, leading into such proposed pipe
culverts, shall be made and pipe culvert sizes determined. Pipe culvert Type 1, 12" inside diameter by 16' long, shall be
considered as the minimum size for private driveways. A pipe culvert of at least the minimum size shall be installed for
each private driveway.
Pipe culverts Type 1, 15" inside diameter by 32' long shall be considered as the minimum size for all crossroad culverts.
All pipe culverts shall be standard strength reinforced concrete culvert pipe.
Rural type street improvements shall also conform to the following as minimum dimensions for construction:
Surface width (traveled portion) 20'0" with a 4" circular arc crown. Shoulder width, 4'0" on each of traveled portion of
surface. (Shoulders to slope from edge of surface 3/4" per foot).
Ditches - Slope on street size 4:1, back slope 2:1.
Two (2) copies of plans of all proposed street improvements, including pipe culvert design, shall be submitted to and
approved by the City prior to the beginning of any construction. (Ord. 1052 § 1)
17-8-12: STORM SEWER CONSTRUCTION:
A. Prior to the construction of any storm sewers, a complete study of the drainage area, leading into such proposed
storm sewers, shall be made and storm sewer sizes determined.
B. Except for storm sewer drainage under driveway entrances, all storm sewer construction shall be of standard strength
concrete prior or vitrified clay tile.
C. No storm sewer shall hereafter be accepted by the City for future maintenance unless and until the subdivision
developershall have first submitted to the City Council their plat of said subdivision showing location, size and
construction of the storm sewer system in said subdivision. (Ord. 1153 § 1)
17-8-13: NOTIFICATION TO CITY PRIOR TO ACCEPTANCE:
A. Streets Or Sidewalks: No streets or sidewalks shall hereafter be accepted by the City for future maintenance unless
and until the subdivision developer shall have first notified the City Council in writing that the developer desires the
City to accept said streets and sidewalks for future maintenance and unless and until the City has determined that
said streets and sidewalks meet the specifications as set forth in this Chapter. (Ord. 1152 § 1)
B. Sanitary Sewer Or Sewers: No sanitary sewer or sewers shall hereafter be accepted by the City for future
maintenance unless or until the builder or subdivision developer shall have first notified the City Council in writing that
the developer or builder desires the City to accept said sanitary sewer or sewers for future maintenance, and unless
and until the City has determined that said sanitary sewer or sewers meet the specifications and are functioning
properly. (Ord. 1163 § 1)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=470 715/923
Chapter 9
STANDARDS FOR EXTENSION OF STREET LIGHTING SYSTEM
17-9-1: PURPOSE:
It is the purpose and intent of this Chapter to establish standards which must be met prior to the erection of new street
lamps and other necessary apparatus and equipment which will extend or increase the street lighting system of the City.
(Ord. 73-8 § 1)
17-9-2: CITY MANAGER'S AUTHORITY:
The City Manager is hereby authorized, subject to the terms and conditions set forth herein, to order from the
appropriate electrical energy furnishing company authorized to do business within the City, the increase or extension of
the street lighting system of the City. (Ord. 73-8 § 2)
17-9-3: AUTHORIZATION OF EXTENSIONS:
The City Council shall, by resolution, annually, authorize the number of locations at which extensions to or increases in
the street lighting system of the City may be made. (Ord. 73-8 § 3)
17-9-4: BUDGET:
The City Council shall, by its annual budget ordinance, establish an account for the extension of the street lighting
system of the City. (Ord. 73-8 § 4)
17-9-5: STANDARDS:
The City Manager may, upon the request of any citizen, or at his own discretion, and subject to the number of new
locations authorized by resolution, and subject to the availability of funds in the street lighting account of the budget of
the City, order an increase or extension of the street lighting system of the City if the proposed location of the increase or
extension of the street lighting system meets the standards set forth herein. The standards for the purpose of this
Section shall be deemed metfor the proposed location if said location contains at least six (6) of the following eleven (11)
elements:
A. Housing: Concentration of housing in the area contiguous to the proposed location does not consist of a mobile home
park, and contains more than one building or structure for every six hundred (600) square feet of space within a
radius of thirty (30) lineal feet from the proposed location.
B. Large Trees: The area within a radius of three hundred (300) lineal feet from the proposed location contains a
concentration of large trees.
C. Public Buildings: The area within a radius of three hundred (300) lineal feet from the proposed location contains a
church, school or other public building.
D. Railroad Crossing: A railroad crossing is within three hundred (300) lineal feet of the proposed location.
E. Traffic Record: The traffic record of the proposed location, and in an area within a radius of three hundred (300) lineal
feet thereof, indicates that more than one accident has occurred within such area within twelve (12) months from the
date of the investigation of said location.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=470 716/923
F. Crime Record: The crime record at the proposed location, and in an area within the radius of five hundred (500) lineal
feet thereof, indicates that more than one criminal offense has been committed within twelve (12) months from the
date of the investigation of said location.
G. Main Thoroughfare: The proposed location is at the intersection of a main thoroughfare.
H. Bus Stop: The proposed location is at a bus stop.
I. Fire Alarm Box: If the proposed location is at a fire alarm box.
J. Street Light: The proposed location does not have a street light within three hundred feet (300') of the proposed
location.
K. Pedestrian Traffic: Pedestrian traffic by the proposed location consists of five hundred (500) or more pedestrians per
day. (Ord. 73-8 § 5)
17-9-6: COUNCIL AUTHORITY:
The standards contained herein must be met prior to the time the City Manager may order the extension of the street
lighting system of the City, are in no way binding or controlling upon the City Council, and said Council may, at any time,
by ordinance, extend the street lighting system of the City. (Ord. 73-8 § 6)
Chapter 10
TREES, BUSHES AND SHRUBS
17-10-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words, and their derivations shall have the meaning given
herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the plural
number include the singular number, and the words in the singular number include the plural number. The word "shall" is
always mandatory and not merely directory.
BUSH: A low densely branched shrub.
DIAMETER BREAST HEIGHT (dbh): The diameter of a tree measured at fifty four inches (54") above the ground.
HERITAGE TREE: Any tree having an eighteen inch (18") or larger dbh.
PERSON: A person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company, or organization of any kind.
PLANT: A living organism of the kind exemplified by trees, shrubs, herbs, grasses, ferns, and mosses, typically growing
in a permanent site, absorbing water and inorganic substances through its roots, and synthesizing nutrients in its leaves
by photosynthesis.
PUBLIC PLACE: Public street right of way and city owned land or property.
SHRUB: A woody perennial plant smaller than a tree with several main perennial stems arising at or near the ground.
TOPPING: The severe cutting back of limbs to stubs larger than three inches (3") in diameter within the tree's crown to
such a degree as to remove the normal canopy and disfigure the tree.
TREE: A wood plant having one erect perennial stem (trunk) at least three inches (3") in diameter with a mature height of
at least thirteen feet (13') planted in a public or private place, except where otherwise indicated.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=470 717/923
TREE SIZES (ORNAMENTAL, SMALL, MEDIUM, AND LARGE): Ornamental trees have an ultimate height of less than
twenty feet (20'). Small trees have an ultimate height of twenty (20) to thirty feet (30') or a fifteen (15) to twenty five foot
(25') spread; medium trees have an ultimate height of thirty (30) to fifty feet (50') or a thirty (30) to forty foot (40') spread;
large trees have an ultimate height of greater than fifty feet (50') or over a forty foot (40') spread.
TRIMMER AND CUTTER: A tree trimmer and cutter means any person who for a fee engages in any manner in pruning,
trimming, cutting, bracing or removal of trees whether the trees in question are diseased or not diseased. (Ord. 2015-22)
17-10-2: AUTHORITY OF CITY MANAGER OR HIS DESIGNEE:
The city manager or his designee shall have exclusive jurisdiction and supervision over all trees, bushes, shrubs or other
plants, and grassy areas planted or growing in public places.
A. Preserve Or Remove: The city manager or his designee shall have the authority, and it shall be his duty, to plant, trim,
spray, preserve and remove trees, bushes, shrubs or other plants and grassy areas in public places to ensure safety
or preserve the symmetry and beauty of such public places.
B. Order To Preserve Or Remove: The city manager or his designee shall have the authority, and it shall be his duty, to
order the trimming, preservation or removal of trees, bushes, shrubs or plants upon private property when he shall
find such action is necessary to protect historic significance, protect heritage trees, ensure public safety or to prevent
the spread of disease or insects to trees, bushes, shrubs or plants in public places or on privately owned land.
C. Supervision: The city manager or his designee shall have the authority, and it shall be his duty, to supervise all work
done under a permit issued in accordance with the terms of this chapter.
D. Uniform Plan: It shall be the public policy of the city to plant trees in accordance with a uniform plan to be determined
by the city manager or his designee along rights of way of all new or reconstructed streets, and where other public
improvements cause trees to be removed.
E. Issue Conditional Permit: The city manager or his designee shall have the authority to affix reasonable conditions to
the grant of a permit hereunder. (Ord. 2015-22)
17-10-3: PUBLIC PLACES; PERMITS REQUIRED:
No person shall plant, set out, trim, spray, preserve or remove trees, bushes, shrubs or other plants in public places
without first filing an application and procuring a permit from the city manager or his designee. Any person granted a
permit to cut down or trim a tree in a public place shall remove all the debris at his own expense.
A. Application Data: The application required herein shall state such information as the city manager or his designee
shall find reasonably necessary to a fair determination of whether a permit should issue hereunder.
B. Standards For Issuance: The city manager or his designee shall issue the permit provided for herein when he finds
that the desired action or treatment is necessary and that the proposed method and workmanship are satisfactory.
C. Regulations For Planting In A Public Place: Work done under a permit issued hereunder shall be performed in strict
accordance with the terms hereof, and with the following regulations established for the planting, trimming and care
of the trees, bushes and shrubs in public places:
1. Trees must not be less than one inch (1") in diameter of trunk one foot (1') above the ground.
2. No tree shall be placed so as, in the opinion of the city manager or his designee, to cause a traffic hazard.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=470 718/923
3. The city forestry division shall maintain a list of prohibited and a list of acceptable trees to be used when planting
trees in a public place. This list will consist of trees currently deemed satisfactory by the city manager or his
designee. The city's forestry division will maintain both prohibited and approved tree lists for public places and
make these lists readily available to the general public. Other trees may be allowed if approved by the city's
forestry division.
4. No tree shall be planted where the clear space between the curb and the sidewalk is less than four feet (4'). Small
trees shall be planted a minimum twenty feet (20') apart, medium trees a minimum thirty feet (30') apart and large
trees a minimum forty feet (40') apart except in special plantings designed by an Illinois licensed landscape
architect and approved by the city manager or his designee.
5. No tree shall be planted where the soil is too poor to ensure growth of such tree unless the owner excavates a
suitable hole of not less than thirty six (36) cubic feet and replaces the material removed with suitable loam or top
soil.
6. No tree, bush or shrub shall be planted nearer than four feet (4') from the curb line or the sidewalk unless a special
permit is granted by the city manager or his designee.
7. No tree, bush or shrub shall be planted or be allowed to remain untrimmed so as to be an obstruction to vision
within a triangular space at a street or alley corner between the heights of three feet (3') and fifteen feet (15') above
the established street grade. The street grade is measured at the intersection of the centerlines of the intersecting
streets, or street and alley pavements; and the triangular space is determined by a diagonal line connecting two (2)
points measured twenty five feet (25') equidistant from the meeting point of the edges of the traveled ways of the
two (2) streets, or street and alley.
8. No medium or large tree varieties are allowed to be planted under overhead utility lines.
9. No spiking with metal spurs or gaffs shall be used to climb live trees for any purpose other than tree removal or
human rescue.
10. It shall be unlawful for any person to place rocks or debris between the trunk and the drip line of any tree in a
public place.
D. Regulations For Removal In A Public Place: Work done under a permit issued hereunder shall be performed in strict
accordance with the terms hereof and with the following regulations established for the removal of trees, bushes and
shrubs in a public place:
1. Unlawful To Remove Trees: It shall be unlawful for any person to remove any tree on city right of way without
written permission from the city manager or his designee.
2. Charge For Removing Trees: If any person removes any tree located on the city right of way, the person shall pay
to the city an amount equal to the value of the tree. The value of the tree shall be determined in accordance with
the most recent "Guide For Plant Appraisal", as published by the International Society Of Arboriculture or its
successor publication. This cost may be waived by the city manager or his designee if it is determined the tree
removal shall be in the best interest of the city.
3. Dead Trees: Any dead tree located in a public place shall be completely removed, including the stump and any
exposed roots. The city may require the replacement of trees removed from public places. (Ord. 2015-22)
17-10-4: GROWING A TREE, BUSH, SHRUB OR PLANT:
A. Duties Of Owner: It shall be the duty of any person growing a tree, bush, shrub or plant within a public place, or
responsible for trees, bushes, shrubs or plants growing on property abutting public places supporting trees, bushes,
shrubs or plants, or on other private property:
1. To trim trees, bushes, shrubs or plants so as not to cause a hazard to public places or interfere with the proper
lighting of public highways by the streetlights, as so that the minimum clearance of any portion overhanging a
public right of way or sidewalk shall be eight feet (8').
2. To treat or remove any tree, bush, shrub or plant so diseased or insect ridden to constitute a hazard to trees or
plants in public places.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=470 719/923
3. To remove any tree or limb of a tree that has become likely to fall.
4. To trim trees, bushes, shrubs, or plants so that they do not obstruct passage on any portion of any sidewalk.
5. Not to allow to grow any vegetation, alternative vegetation, trees, bushes or shrubs which are otherwise prohibited
by law, including, but not limited to, noxious weeds as prohibited by the Illinois noxious weed law.
6. Not to plant any tree, bush or shrub within four feet (4') of the public right of way line or sidewalk.
B. Obstruction Or Danger To Traffic Or Passage: The city manager or his designee may trim or remove any tree, bush,
shrub, or plant so that the obstruction or danger to traffic or passage shall be done away with. (Ord. 2015-22)
17-10-5: PROCEDURE UPON ORDER TO PRESERVE OR REMOVE:
When the city manager or his designee shall find it necessary to order the trimming, preservation or removal of trees,
bushes, shrubs, or plants upon private property as authorized in section 17-10-2 of this chapter, he shall serve a written
order to correct the dangerous condition upon the owner, operator, occupant or other person responsible for its
existence.
A. Method Of Service: The order required herein shall be served in one of the following ways:
1. By making personal delivery of the order to the person responsible.
2. By leaving the order with some person of suitable age and discretion upon the premises.
3. By affixing a copy of the order to the door at the entrance of the premises in violation.
4. By mailing a copy of the order to the last known address of the owner of the premises, by registered mail.
B. Time For Compliance: The order required herein shall set forth a time limit for compliance, dependent upon the
hazard and danger created by the violation. In cases of extreme danger to persons or public property, the city
manager or his designee shall have the authority to require compliance immediately upon service of the order.
C. Appeal From Order: A person to whom an order hereunder is directed shall have the right, within twenty four (24)
hours of the service of such order, to appeal to the city council by filing written notice of such appeal to the city
manager. The city council shall review such order and appeal at its next regularly scheduled meeting and render its
decision thereon. Unless the order is revoked or modified, it shall remain in full force and be obeyed by the person to
whom directed. No person to whom an order is directed shall fail to comply with such order within the time directed
after an appeal shall have been determined.
D. Failure To Comply: When a person to whom an order is directed fails to comply within the specified time, the city
manager or his designee shall remedy the condition or contract with others for such purpose and charge the cost
thereof to the person to whom the order is directed. The person remedying a condition under a contract made
hereunder shall be authorized to enter premises for that purpose.
E. Notice Of Lien: If the cost of remedying a condition is not paid within thirty (30) days after receipt of a statement
therefor from the city manager or his designee, a notice of lien of the cost and expense thereof incurred shall be
recorded in the following manner: The city shall file notice of lien in the office of the recorder of deeds, Jackson
County, Illinois. Such notice of lien shall contain a description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof, the
amount of money representing the cost and expense incurred or payable for the service and the date or dates when
said costs and expenses were incurred. Such notice shall be under oath and shall be filed within sixty (60) days after
the costs and expenses are incurred. Such liens are assessed to recover the expenses incurred by the city and shall
not serve as an exemption from any penalties imposed for the violation of this chapter. (Ord. 2015-22)
17-10-6: ABUSE OR MUTILATION OF TREES, BUSHES, SHRUBS OR PLANTS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=470 720/923
Except as authorized herein, no person shall:
A. Damage Or Remove Trees, Bushes, Shrubs Or Plants: Damage, cut, carve, transplant or remove any tree, bush,
shrub or plant in a public place, or injure the bark;
B. Pick Flowers Or Seeds: Pick the flowers or seeds of any tree, bush, shrub or plant in a public place;
C. Attach Any Contrivance: Attach any rope, wire, sign, or other contrivance to any tree, bush, shrub or plant in a public
place;
D. Injure Or Impair: Dig in or otherwise disturb grass areas, or in any way injure or impair the natural beauty or
usefulness of any public place;
E. Allow Contact With Harmful Substance Or Electricity: Cause or permit any wire charged with electricity to come in
contact with any tree, bush, shrub, or plant in a public place or allow any gaseous, liquid, or solid substance which is
harmful to such trees, bushes, shrubs or plants to come in contact with them.
F. Topping Of Trees: Cause or allow the topping of any tree in the city of Carbondale. Trees severely damaged by storms
or other causes, or certain trees under utility wires or other obstructions may be exempted as authorized by the city
manager or his designee.
G. Removal Of Trees: Except as provided in section 17-10-9 of this chapter, remove, allow, or cause to be removed any
heritage tree without first obtaining a permit from the city manager or his designee; said permit shall include the
requirement to replant an appropriate replacement tree, as approved by the city forestry division, on the same
property upon which the heritage tree was removed within six (6) months of the heritage tree removal date.
Replacement trees shall be minimum one inch (1") diameter of trunk at twelve inches (12") above the ground.
Removal of multiple heritage trees shall require multiple replacement trees as determined appropriate by the city
manager or his designee. (Ord. 2015-22)
17-10-7: TREE TRIMMER AND CUTTER LICENSE REQUIRED:
Except as provided in section 17-10-9 of this chapter, it shall be unlawful for any person to act or operate as a tree
trimmer and/or cutter within the corporate limits of the city of Carbondale without obtaining a license prior thereto. A
license shall not be required of any public service utility company employee or city employee doing such work in the
pursuit of their public service endeavors. However a license is required for any contractor or subcontractor that is hired
by any public service utility company or the city to perform tree trimming and/or cutting work. The city clerk will maintain
and make a list of licensed tree trimmers and cutters available to the general public.
